description:
Imperial Tea was decorated really nicely despite being located in the Ferry Building. Getting seated was a breeze. The service was very helpful as well.

The noodles (both the thinner and thicker noodles) were tasty, and the broth was also delicious. I ordered the thinner ones (think basic spaghetti noodles, and a LOT of them), but I liked the thick noodles best. The dumpling platter was also tasty, and the assorted dumplings came out hot and fresh! It was a great platter to share in addition to our soup (which can also easily be shared). I would skip the pork bun, however, and stick with the noodles. While the bun looked absolutely delicious, it wasn't anything special (I prefer the Costco microwave ones to this). 

Even though our friend called the soup pho like 500 times (she was clearly confused on the type of food we were eating), she seemed to fully enjoy her soup as well. 

Overall it was a good experience and an easy way to temporarily avoid the Saturday crowds.
author: Heather R.

description:
Ok for a tea serving show but everything lacks flavor.
If you're looking for light eats minus well go to a hospital for a meal.
Disappointing wonton and noodles soup.
author: Leong R.

description:
This is a Chinese tea/food shop located in the Ferry Building. It feels a bit out of place compared to the rest of the shops in the Ferry Building but it's worth a visit if you like Chinese tea!

The prices are kind of high but I guess it's because of how expensive the rent is. For example, one order of genmai tea was $8 but to be fair you do get to see the staff wash the tea for you and pour you the first cup. You get a pot of hot water so you can reuse the tea leaves for quite a long time.

I got the handmade noodles with beef and thought it was pretty decent. I got mild spicy and thought it was tolerable. Flavor was decent. I did like the chewiness of the noodles that I got here. They were nice and wide. The other noodle dish has thinner noodles.
author: Danielle C.

description:
As I was walking down the main walkway, saw a guest with a steamed bun. I immediately looked around to find where she bought it. Low and behold, they had their steam buns right up in the front! I hadn't had a steamed BBQ pork bun in a long time. My stomach growled!

For a whopping $3, the steamed bun did not excite my taste buds. The bun was fluffy and soft, but the BBQ pork inside was very plain and needed more seasoning. It was very moist inside, but just lacked flavor overall. 

I still chowed it down, cause I paid that whopping $3. Oh, and no credit card purchases under $6. Such an odd value. Oh well, I had cash anyways. Usually am prepared with some cash when I'm on a vacation.
author: Antonio L.

description:
I've been to the Ferry building many times and passed by this restaurant many many times too  
And last Sunday was the first time, it's the best to experience the tea service! 
The gentleman helped us to understand how to make the good tea! It's simple but steps by steps! 
The lychee blossom smell really good! 
The food was good! Especially the tea noodles taste really delicious and little "weird" to my kids ! 
Just enjoy tea time !
author: Truc M.

description:
It really doesn't feel like you're in the Ferry Building when you're at Imperial Tea Court.  It's so quiet &  not at all crazy busy.  I appreciated that & found it so refreshing.

With impending dinner plans approaching, this was just a stop for something quick to eat before leaving the building.  Steamed buns from the front vendor, & a milk tea.

Trying both the barbecue pork bun & the savory pork bun; both were light & fluffy, but the barbecue pork definitely won this round.  And adding hot sauce elevated it further.  The savory bun, on the other hand, had a sauce that was almost gel like in consistency, & the meat seemed undercooked.  It had an aspect of questionable to it.  Pass.

The milk tea was delicious.  Not too sweet, which is my natural preference.  Win.

Good for a pick me up, but food can be hit or miss.

3 stars.
author: Veronica M.

description: Got a BBQ Pork Bun and a Sweet Red Bean Bun for $3 each. The service was very quick. The buns were steaming hot out of the bins. Both of them taste good (typical).
author: Yuan Z.

description:
Imperial Tea Court is very touristy and expensive for Chinese food. It's in the Ferry Building so it's totally understandable. They gotta pay their astronomical rent somehow right? 

IF I brought my Tiger mom here for their $15 Bowl of Noodle Soup, it would be akin to getting a 96% on a school exam. 

"You got an 'A'?!...AIYA, what happened to A plus-y?!?" 

I would be eating feathers for the week.... 

If you grew up with a Tiger Mom too, you know what's up!

My boss loves this place and suggested it for a lunch with our old co-worker. It's a tea house and they have fancy tea service but we came for the food. The small menu has dim sum, steamed buns, noodle soups, curry, and cookies. No msg is used which I confirmed with our server.  

As we were perusing the menu, my old co-worker bought some steamed buns from their stand in front. The Cha Siu Bao ($3): http://bit.ly/2o676Zd was hot, fluffy, and chockful of savory sweet roasted pork. It was decent. While it's twice the cost of Chinese bakeries, keep in mind it's the Ferry Building so $3 is not too shabby for a snack. 

She also bought a Pork Meatball Bao ($3) which was terrible. The dense filling tasted like old siu mai filling. 

We all opted for the Prix-Fixe Lunch ($22): Choice of Entrée, Spring Roll, Almond Cookies, and Tea (+$3 for Imperial Tea). 

My boss raves about their noodle soup so I ordered the Hand-Stretched Noodle Soup w/ Braised Beef for my entrée: http://bit.ly/2Asr8yw.

The hand stretched noodles were firm but lacked a chewy bite: http://bit.ly/2zcXMWX. The broth is available in mild, medium, and spicy. The medium was pretty spicy and overpowered the taste of the broth. We were told the broth is vegetable based so that may also be the reason why I couldn't taste any depth (if there was any). 

The braised beef needed to be cooked at least another 45 minutes longer as the larger pieces were a bit tough.

The accompanying spring roll was horrific and was like eating toasted parchment paper. While I appreciate the healthy approach of baking instead of frying it, the wrapper was busted at the seams and the cabbage filling was completely flavorless. We asked for sweet & sour sauce which they didn't have but our server brought us their housemade hibiscus dipping sauce. It was bizarre...it was like eating pureed flowers and sugar. 

The almond cookies were meh. I was expecting them to be like shortbread cookies but they weren't. They should just serve almond cookies from Twin Dragon (pink box). 

For the tea, I choose the caffeine-free Prosperity Blend (hibiscus based). It was floral and a little too sweet for my liking. 

Service was great. The young server with black hair and glasses was super friendly and there when we needed her. 

Aside from their noodle soup, my boss loves this place because it's quiet and you can easily maintain a conversation compared to all the other places in the Ferry Building. He was right. There's only 6-7 four tops and there wasn't a crowd during primetime lunchtime. 

The Ferry Building is fantastic and has lots of great stands and eateries like Acme, Cowgirl Creamery, Hog Island Oysters Co, Delica, etc. but this is not one of them. As much as my boss loves this place, the food at Imperial Tea is a very poor representation of Chinese food in San Francisco. Go to The Sunset or The Richmond for legit Chinese food!
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
After having a killer run on Embarcadero, we thought we deserved some hearty tasty dim sum! So we decided to check out Imperial Tea Court at the Ferry Building. I've always seen this place serving up steam buns at a stand directly outside the restaurant to attract the farmers market foot traffic inside the building. The dim sum menu seems promising and interesting/unique but overall after trying it, I have to say the food was lackluster and you can find better dim sum elsewhere.

We ordered the following:
1) Shrimp Dumplings: While the filling in this was decently flavorful, the dumplings were so tiny and the dumpling skin was insanely thin. Every time we picked one up with our chopsticks, the skin would just fall apart and the filling would come out. Not a great experience.

2) Dragon Well Dumplings: The skin on these was definitely better, but I found the filling to be bland and had to dip the dumpling in soy sauce and chili oil to taste something. I get the uniqueness of flavoring the filling with a tea seasoning, but I think there needs to be some other flavor component. 

3) Wontons in Jasmine Tea Broth: This dish sounded super unique, and it definitely was. I'll give the restaurant plus points for the size of this dish (I think there were 10-12 wontons). But, while the tea-infused broth gave it an interesting spin, the flavors weren't balanced. The jasmine tea from the broth combined with the peppercorn in the filling made the wontons bitter. This dish again needed something else to have complementing flavors (something salty, fatty, or sweet ideally). 

Overall, I think the food was just okay. It's not a bad place to come to if you're in the area craving dim sum, but it by no means comes close to solid dim sum spots around town.
author: Sabina S.

description: I was very surprised by this place. I've never come in since I thought it was just tea and snacks but they have a lunch menu as well. We all ordered soups which were delicious, basic but delicious. I was pleasantly surprised! The server was very friendly as well and gave a nice presentation when serving our teas. We will definitely remember this place for another lunch date!
author: Berry L.

description:
Got a steamed bbq pork bun to snack on while walking around the Ferry building from the cart.  I did not eat at their sit down restaurant. 

The bao was hot and fresh from the bamboo steamer.  However, it was more bao than char siu.  

The flavor of the pork was good, just wished their was more of it.
author: Cindy G.

description:
BRAISED CHICKEN DISH REVIEW 

I work near the  Ferry Building and like to try the different food options available. I was craving Chinese and decided to give Imperial Tea Court a try. I ordered the braised chicken ($16.00). I was disappointed by the small portion of the dish, unfortunately I was not about to take a picture, but it was the size of a medium plate. My disappointment disappeared once I had a bite, it was delicious. The broth of the chicken hid underneath the chicken, rice and broccoli. It was flavorful with spices. If you add the chili offered with, it taste even better.
author: Michelle G.

description:
This spot is a cool little teahouse in the Ferry building. You can get some steamed buns to go if you're in a rush or just want to make a food crawl stop. 

They have a large selection of teas and we tried the peach blossom, which was very fragrant and hits the spot for tea lovers. Their hand made noodles are delicious and they come in broth with your choice of meat. I got ground pork but beef is probably better. 

Service is good. Only downsides are limited seating and kind of expensive so I wouldn't recommend coming on an empty stomach. 

Food: 4/5
Value: 3/5
Service: 4/5
Overall: 3.75/5
author: Brian G.

description: Amazing! I had the pork steamed bun and sweet red bean steamed bun with lychee tea. The tea was light and refreshing. The steamed buns were delicious and made me miss Japan. They were definitely foods I could eat every day if I lived here!
author: Jennifer L.

description:
Five stars for their amazing steamed pork buns. At $3 each and served from a foldable card table in front of Imperial Court, these will not disappoint. The buns are humongous (think large fist) and packed with so much sweet/savory porky goodness you'll be ordering a second. For condiments they have soy sauce and a deliciously hot chili paste that cuts right through the fatty pork, a must. 

Wether you're hung over and waiting for a ferry, or just hungry for a truly delicious steam bun, these are what you need in your life.
author: Alexander C.

description: Had pork bun and savory pork bun. Both were good, i think i like normal pork bun better.  Would pork bun again.
author: Michael E.

description:
The staff was nice and accommodating but omg, I didn't think it was possible to make bad boba tea (I make it myself at home. It's easy). I was wrong.

I asked if I could get boba in the hibiscus iced tea, was told sure. Learned that their iced tea is not sweetened at all, which is a bad match for boba (especially boba that has no syrup, for some reason?) Wish I'd been told this, but the customer asked, so I'll excuse it.

What's inexcusable is how terrible the boba itself was. Wildly inconsistent, with lots of really undercooked pieces. I like my boba chewier than most people but I got 2-3 HARD pieces in my first few sips and completely gave up on it. Really disappointing.
author: Colleen R.

description:
It's very obvious this place is a tourist trap and only has business due to the location. They charge $3 for ONE BBQ pork bun, which contained rubbery pork that was unchewable. 

The sign said "$3 BBQ Pork Buns" - which implies that $3 will get you more than one bun since "buns" is plural. When I noted this to the cashier, who spoke English, she said I don't know what you're saying. And just ignored me. Nice.
author: Bernardette O.

description: At the ferry building, this was quaint and unexpected delight. Primarily because the wait staff was very nice, pleasant and helpful. Tee was awesome.
author: She H.

description: You can definitely get better overall dim sum elsewhere in the city, but I would say the bbq pork buns here are my favorite (size of bun, bun:meat ratio, bun texture). Also a really great selection of teas. Not sure if I would sit down to dine again, but I'll always stop to grab a bun from the stand in front of the restaurant when walking around the Ferry Building.
author: Lynn T.

description:
I really like Imperial Tea Court's quick to-go option of steamed buns and tea eggs. It's fast and convenient and still fresh and hot when they serve it to you. I've tried the regular pork and BBQ pork and both are delicious. For $6 you get two, which I think is a decent deal.

However, if you're looking for a stellar dimsum dining experience, this isn't really the place for you. The tea-infused dumplings and shumai are really tiny (they are more like a small snack than part of a meal) and I thought they tasted mediocre at best. For $6 a plate, you get 6 small pieces of each. I imagine their tea is pretty good though, but I didn't get a chance to try any.
author: Alice S.

description:
I'm a sucker for tea and noodles now that I've been here! Came here with hubby on our second day on vacation in San Francisco. It was raining. We were soaked through and freezing. 
We had their homemade noodles in veggie broth. He had chicken n pork. I had vegan. We also had shrimp dumplings. I truly enjoyed both n am ready for a nap now that my tummy is feeling good. 
Also, I'm pretty sure there's a magic tea out there that will cure all my ills and make me cool as hell and I think it can be found here.
author: kim v.

description:
Boooooo! Their spring roll had only boring vegetables and no flavor in it! 

Their BBQ pork buns had a sad color to it. No bright red and pink color to denote the sweet sweet barbeque meat flavor. The meat was more gray than pink, and was questionable whether it was even supposed to be eaten. 

Additionally, their HK milk tea was so watered down and had no sweetness to it. So sad that this had to be my friends first time trying HK milk tea and had to explain to them that they shouldn't knock it off their list just because this place did a bad job. 

Save your money and go to a real dim sum place. This place is a hack.
author: Edmund L.

description: Their freshly steamed buns are good but they're not anything surprising. You can totally get the same buns from local hole in the walls. They taste exactly the same. I got the popular bbq pork which I know my mom's filipino steamed bun taste better. This place is just alright but I'm giving a 3 star because of the decor and designed layout of this restaurant especially being inside a Ferry Building. It's amazing!
author: Allister D.

description: The best beef noodle in SF, they have different types of noodles that you can choose, but the service was really slow.
author: Sydney W.

description: Disappointing, go to China Town or Shandong in Oakland. Wontons we're under seasoned while the dragon dumplings had great seasoning but almost raw doughy exterior.
author: Sanjay R.

description:
We were looking forward to a cup of hot tea and a light snack after shopping at the Ferry Building Marketplace. 

The tea was served luke warm with a crappy attitude.  We did not have high expectations for the dim sum; but pork buns with wet bottoms are just not acceptable.  

The pork buns with wet bottoms were pointed out to the server...and she was not responsive.  We left the pork buns for the Imperial Tea to put into their compost bin. 

A big disappointment to a fun day of shopping at Ferry Building Marketplace.
author: Lucky L.

description: We visited the Ferry Building in on Saturday during the lunchtime rush and bought one of the pork belly buns ($5) they were cooking/selling off a stand in front of the actual restaurant space. The pork belly itself was delicious and well-flavored, but the bun was too wet and started falling apart on the second bite.
author: Janice L.

description: Cashier was rude when asked of bun ingredients. For $3.00 a bun thinking must be good. Bought two. Small amounts of bbq with more fat than pork. Disappointed!
author: dan w.

description:
Imperil Tea Court is a nice quiet oasis in the midst of the bustling market in the Ferry Building. I met someone here for a business meeting and we enjoyed some exceptional tea and also some peace and quiet.  

The server takes time to explain how to properly brew and serve your tea.  Here you will learn not only how to clean the leaves but also how to pour it from the kettle (which isn't as easy as you'd think!)

I'd give all five stars but it is pretty expensive for just one cup of tea.  However, you are in the midst of a very touristy place so most of the prices at the restaurants are going to be a bit inflated.
author: Mara K.

description: Tasty place for a Sunday tea break. Dim sum came piping hot from the steamer BBQ pork was better than savory pork.  Also got the original stretched noodles with beef and the shrimp how gaw which came in 6 tiny little balls.
author: Maria M.

description:
This review is for the steamed buns only.

I've always walked by and saw steamers full of pork buns. I randomly decided to try them. At $3 it's pretty expensive, but everything in the Ferry Building is expensive. I tried the barbecue pork bun - the dough was soft and light, but I didn't like the filling. I also saw pork belly buns sitting in the steamer and decided to try one. To my surprise, they were actually $5 per bun - $5!! She didn't bother to tell me until I was holding the bun in a to-go tray :/ Anyway, the filling was great but in this case the dough seemed a lot denser, less light and airy, and a bit stale along the edges. Overall, as I expected, the experience was average and perhaps more targeted toward tourists. Better, cheaper options are available all over SF.
author: Wayne H.

description:
Interior - Beautiful with gorgeous teapots.

Pork belly buns - $5 of juicy, savory, soft, and hot gooey pork. Each person should have one for themselves. 

Shu mai - So awful that it was memorable. Will not order again. 

The interior is beautiful and teapots are nice to look at.
author: Ee Vonn Y.

description:
It's a gimmicky place in the Ferry Building, so I guess my expectations shouldn't be so high in the first place. Imperial Tea Court is decorated the way you'd think a "traditional" tea house would be, but with an exposed ceiling that reminds you that you're just in a part-hipster, part-tourist part of the city.

The food wasn't anything special. I got a tea egg and my friend got the BBQ pork bao at alarmingly expensive rates (I think it was close to $9 total?), considering that Chinatown isn't far away. Although the tea egg looked well-marbled from the shell, it didn't taste like it had been steeped for long enough for the tea flavor to really settle in. The bao was large and the meat-to-bun ratio was great, but again, at $6, I have to question if it's worth it. Service wasn't terrible considering we interacted for all of two minutes, just to exchanged money for some goods.

When I'm in the Ferry Building next, I'm going to pass and hope that Roli Roti is outside so I can eat a quarter of a rotisserie chicken for a snack instead. I can't vouch for Imperial Tea Court's tea or other dim sum, but I don't think I can afford it.
author: Gwen W.

description: The best BBQ pork Buns  I always come back for the same thing! A couple of bbq pork buns and a bottle of their ginger ale will be perfect for a quick lunch break.
author: Angel M.

description:
I can only vouch for the quality of their tea and their service, but what we did experience was very enjoyable.

The young man who served us was very friendly and had a clear passion for the high-quality tea he served. He enjoyed giving in-depth information on where the tea comes from, etc.

We splurged and bought a cup of their most expensive tea, which was $18. It lasted about six, satisfying cups.

If you have some time to kill at the Ferry Building, this tea shop is a great place to hang out while enjoying some fine tea.
author: Ross M.

description: The food in here is so expensive, the shrimp dumplings are so small it's like one tiny bite,you can eat while plate. I got way better food in Chinatown.
author: Clancy Y.

description: Lovely place for good tea. I had forgotten about the tea court. My wife and I were wandering around killing time before leaving town. We came across the tea court. We had been there a few years ago. It was just as good as it was then.
author: Joseph J.

description: This place seemed mediocre at best, I liked the tea we chose (lychee Black tea I believe) and the pork buns as swell as the shrimp dumplings were pretty good. The spring rolls were a no go for me, but overall it was an ok lunch. For $35 I expected a little more though. Would recommend getting the shrimp dumplings and the bbq pork buns though!
author: Olivia J.

description: What a lovely setting for some nice conversation over tea and snacks! The tables and decorations here are beautiful and oriental. Being sensitive to caffeine, I got the organic rooibos (an herbal tea), and it was steeped from a tea bag with a kettle of hot water. The tea was warming and calming, and on the side, we got the chicken and lamb dumplings to nibble on, along with the snack platter consisting of almonds and two different kinds of cookies. The food that we tried was not particularly special, and everything was pricey for what you got. Nevertheless, this was a nice place to sit and chat, and our server was friendly and took the time to explain the teas to us!
author: David K.

description:
On my way from Super Bowl 50, I wanna have something to eat for lunch since it's past 3 pm.  So I've decided where I can eat in.  I headed inside the Ferry Building and into an Imperial Tea Court.  Surely there were most people who had their tables; fortunately, a kind female server with glasses have found a table for me.  All she had to do was to clean the table for me and I'm seated.  This was my first time having lunch inside the open restaurant.  I wanted to talk to the other American version of Jimmy who owns the tea selection, but he wasn't here today.  I'll sometimes swing by his position during lunchtime and after work M-F to see how he's doing.  

Since I had $25 with me, I ordered a curry vegan tofu with rice and a glass of hibiscus ice tea.  Despite much wait, my plate came to me at last.  Everything I've tasted on my plate was almost bland, but comfortable.  Not much I described about the firm tofu cubes and vegetables; one thing interested me more was the hibiscus ice tea.  Its cranberryish flavor is much better than the Hawaiian Punch.

Since I couldn't have a dessert, I decided to pay.  Upon looking at my receipt, it showed me that I was in table 7.  Made me lucky since 7 was the lucky number!  What I'm lucky about was the total was ten cents less than my $20 bill!  I didn't need a change and I had to give a $1 tip to the female server.  That was a good experience; much better than any Chinese restaurants.  If I wanted a greater experience, an afternoon tea special was what I expected, but it's only M-F 3-6pm.  Plus, I missed the Indian style seating area aligned to the right.  Darn!  I might come and have lunch the second time in the future.
author: Jimmy C.

description:
It's located right in the ferry building so it's easy to get to and find. We were seated quickly even during the dinner rush. 

We ordered two types of dumplings (can't remember which ones). However, we went with 4 people and though they'd be enough to share but they were so small. Service was meh and they weren't too attentive to our group even though we were the only ones there. 

Don't think i'll be coming back since I can easily get my dumpling fix somewhere else in China Town.
author: Keizzel C.

description:
Upscale Chinese food... we've learned our lesson already spending $11.50 for a plate of BBQ pork fried rice (+$1 additional for a runny egg) at Chubby Noodle for something that would have cost $6 at any normal non-hipster Chinese place. 

Plus Imperial Tea Court's placement in the somewhat-touristy Ferry Building automatically puts me on guard and in self-restrained window-shopping mode. But when you are walking around on a weekend with Humphry Slocombe in one hand and Instagram-ready camera phone in the other, one does not simply pass by a stand serving delicious giant dim sum. 

The giant egg rolls and giant steamed bao ($3) are likely just giant forms of dim sum similar to what you can find at 99 Ranch, but... giant dim sum is nonetheless a mouth-watering sight.

We went with the giant pork belly bun ($5) because it seemed more unique than the other options. It was stuffed quite full with pork belly (not the absolute best I've had, but very good) and reminded me of TW rou burger and also of Chairman Bao, only more basic without the gimicky garnishes and in a more convenient hand-held pocket where the filling doesn't fall out. 

Although their stand is located outside their stall, you may sit in the tall majestic wooden chairs of the tea house--the ambiance brings you back a few centuries in zen-like peacefulness away from the hustle and bustle of the Ferry Building marketplace. 

Street food for SF bourgeois.
author: Edna C.

description: The food here is terrible TERRIBLE FOOD! And not only that the tea was not worth the expensive price they charged. There was an tea selection that cost $18 per cup, not pot. I usually love tea but here it was a meh. For the price we paid her, I would rather got to Hog Oyster Co and pay the same for seafood. Here the dim sum did not taste authentic was poorly made. Spend your money elsewhere.
author: Alice L.

description:
Wayy too salty! Was looking for a quick bite so I got the pork sandwich and pork belly steamed bun. Both super underwhelming... My total was about $8. 

It's located in the ferry building in SF, which is super cool!! There are a bunch of cool eateries and shops, along with a farmers market (don't think it's daily, though). 

Place was mehh. Not a fan
author: Katherine S.

description: Best teas that you can buy come from here. It is backed by a real tea master. Try the red envelope tea. It is perfectly ballanced so that no sweetners are needed. Great place to sit down with friends and have a world class tea experience
author: Dustin F.

description: Loved the noodles here. Good options for vegetarians . Teas are great as well . Did by try the dumplings here
author: Jalaj A.

description:
Tried big size steamed buns,tea house noodles and Gaiwan teawith dimsum..good stuff.

Got immediate seating arranged.
author: Priyanka L.

description: Raw meat / raw wonton. Still charge me 80% of the price for the poor service. Even if this is fully cooked, the taste is not good.
author: Shi J.

description: I have gotten so much ugliness in the form of direct messaging from the owner, staff, and his friends since I wrote this post years ago that I had to block several individuals. Not the kind of business I want to patronize.
author: Laurie N.

description: Review limited to pork buns for now... it is good, but didn't match or surpass one of my references for pork buns.... Sunset bakery
author: Richard C.

description: Even 1 star is too high - nasty tasting veggie bun and very below average spring roll and at $3 a piece not worth it.  Went to the take out stand today, Saturday, and a mean and nasty old woman trash talked to me because I wanted a take out box - NOT a open paper plate.  Poor customer service and expensive awful food.
author: G. T.

description: Average for vegetarians. Noodles and bun what we ordered, noodles were good but veggie bun is ok. Not too delicious but is good if you don't have any better option
author: Gaurav C.

description: There was a take out stand in front of the concession and they were selling a few dim sum items of which one was a vegetarian bao.  I am always looking for good vegetarian food, so I tried the vegetarian bao and it was horrible!  Absolutely tasteless!  It was filled with some chopped up leafy bitter greens and all you can taste was the bitterness - worst vegetarian bao EVER.  I will never go back.  Save your money and go to a real dim sum restaurant, where I've had excellent vegetarian baos and food.  It's insulting in a foodie place like SF to have such a substandard restaurant like the Imperial Tea Court.
author: Evelyn W.

description:
lunch @$35 for 2 people. a bit pricey, menu has limited options. 

It's either vegetarian or beef/pork really at this place, the only chicken item is curry -- and they can't add chicken to any of their entrees/dishes.

here's what $35 gets you:
- tea egg ($3/each): run of the mill... 
- vegetarian spring rolls ($6 for 2): baked, but pretty oily. also run of the mill, didn't enjoy the sweet/sour sauce
- shrimp dumplings ($6 for 6 small): very shrimpy tasting, and the outside fell apart. been in the steamer too long
- hand made noodles ($15/bowl): really liked the texture of the noodles and the bowl was pretty spicy. just not sure that i can justify $15 for lunch for 1 bowl -- could be fine to split


TLDR: overall, this place to me has more of a novelty factor -- come for a snack, come for tea, but not if you're hankering for a filling lunch.
author: Kristie C.

description: Very bland, tasteless. The bun was so tasteless that I had to give the second bun to my dog. The saomai  was the worst I have ever had. The boba in the bubble tea was not cooked through. And the wonton was tasteless and boring. Probably the worst Chinese restaurant I ever had in SF. Spent $60+ for two people and was totally not worth it. I'm an Asian growing up with eating Chinese food, and this is just wrong.
author: Kate H.

description:
Ok where to begin .......... This is a beautiful Place. The setting is so Right its storybook gorgeous but, unfortunately it was bland the dumplings were just ok. The menu descriptions sound better than they  tasted. wait staff were nice but not very welcoming and  when I eat chinese food I expect bold flavor. Unfortunately this resturant was just to safe
  in regards to  flavor profile. I really  enjoyed the tea service and so did my kids they had a nice time drinking out of a small petite cups.  portion to price ratio was a huge problem  and that is why I won't be returning.
author: Melanie L.

description: Delish! Loved all the veggie dim sum options. The service is SLOW, but they do have a HIRING sign. I hope they hire someone soon cause this place is fantastic. Tea was good. I was able to watch the bun sale and it was non stop. Its expensive for what you get, but then again its the Ferry building. Its more the experience than the food (though I really did like my dishes). Definitely worth checking out.
author: Ceecee M.

description:
My husband and I visited the Ferry Building for lunch before a movie and needed to find a place to eat that didn't take too long. We passed by this tea shop, which had no line and advertised hand stretched noodles, so we decided to try it. We were pleasantly surprised! We both ordered the hand drawn noodles with beef and it was very tasty. I got mild, which was still spicy. My husband ordered medium and he said it was a bit too spicy. The broth was flavorful, the noodles a good texture, and the beef was relatively good (although I got a couple of pieces that could have been more tender). This is clearly a place geared towards tourists. The decorations were nice, with cute tea sets everywhere. The prices were high, $16 for a bowl of beef noodle soup, but what do you expect from an eatery at the Ferry Building? The service was friendly, although they never refilled our water. I had also ordered the Dragonwell tea with roses and it was very aromatic and relatively strong. They wash the tea for you and then show you how to use a gaiwan to steep the tea before pouring it into your teacup. It was cute to try.

Overall, I would definitely go back!
author: Alice P.

description: I appreciate the tea concept and the attention to detail re: serving tea, but the dishes we tried were bland and small. I wouldn't go out of my way for this place.
author: Paulina F.

description:
Spent all our time here waiting... Waiting to be seated.  Waiting to get menus.  Waiting to get water.  Waiting to take our order.  Waiting to get food.

Once the food did come out, it was plate by plate with 10 minutes in between each. 

Services sucks.

Food taste like frozen Costco dumplings.  Actually, I'd bet the Costco ones are better
author: Gabriel A.

description:
The only thing good about the place was the food. The food is always good here. But what I would say takes the cake with the two stars is the service.

Unapologetic people always irritate me. I'm fine with terrible service, but the fact that there was no apology, not even something to say that they know they're busy is what irritates me. 

Joy, in particular, was terrible. She never once came to our table a part from asking us our order and taking our money. Mind you, we understand that it's a Wednesday between lunch time, but we arrived at the restaurant at 12:30, and were not served food until 1:20. Joy, then, proceeded to tell us that we had only been waiting twenty minutes. Honey, that's not true. I think I know how long I've waited. 

I also had to get up, serve myself some water in which I had other customers ask me questions. There was nobody on the floor. 

So, to chalk it up, at least the food was good, and I'll definitely call in to get my food to go, but I will NEVER sit in this restaurant again. 

Thanks Joy!
author: Stephanie C.

description:
I've eaten here twice before, and while it is overpriced and kitschy, the noodle dishes and tea flavored dim sum are tasty (not a fan of the pork buns). 

However today was just really awful service. Just waiting, due to scattered and unprofessional service. There are many other options for  food and the chance to shop at quality and historical businesses at the Ferry Building - FYI!
author: S. A. K.

description:
We stopped in for a quiet cup of tea and something to nibble on.  We thought the tea and pork belly buns were to much for what you get.

Go if you want to sit somewhere quiet.
author: R P.

description:
I have been a client since the late 90's  (esp. at the Powell Street location) . Other than Red Blossom Tea, ITC has the best green tea and pu-erh tea collection. 

Being a tea lover, there is nothing like a good cup of tea in the morning.  If you are a tea lover and happened to be in downtown S/F. This is the place to go to.  ...
author: Marshal L.

description:
If there was a more gringo Dim Sum spot than Yank Sing (http://www.yelp.com/biz/yank-sing-san-francisco-2), it might just be here at the Embacadero in Imperial Tea Court. To featured Americanized stuff is never a terrible thing, so as long as it's done well. And that's primarily my problem with Imperial, nothing I've had here has lived up to the expectations, or the price tag.

It's easy to fall privy to this touristy spot, after all it is the Embarcadero after all. The allure of the antiquated Asian decor and signs of "organic" love for their samples and treats, is usually enough to compel a small crowd to come here. Rarely crowded, the wait time is typically nil.

Curious to try their famous Teahouse spicy noodles ($12), we opted for the vegetarian version. The broth had some kick to it, but the noodles were a bit too chewy to enjoy. An order of their Dim Sum sampler ($13) was somewhat laughable, considering how poorly executed it all was. A mix of a spring roll, shao mai, a red bean bun, and shrimp dumplings, were dry, somewhat tasteless, and the texture for each was strange. If organic Dim Sum is supposed to be like this, then this is an experiment gone wrong.

We weren't going to give up so easily. We threw in an extra order of the dragon dumplings, which in spite of their initial clump appearance tasted solid. Not sure if they were worth the $6/7 for the plate, but it was easily the best thing I ate. Next up was wonton soup, with a jasmine tea base. While the broth was solid, the wontons were just a mess. The skin was falling apart and the shrimp was overcooked. Not ideal by any means.

Last but not least, the extra star comes as a result of their tea tasting. There are some high quality leaves available here, but it all comes at a pretty price. Are there less spendy variations in Chinatown and The Richmond? Most likely yes. Are the less inhibited / more intimidated likely to choose price and convenience over the rest? Depends on which side of the Dim Sum coin you're on.
author: Jando S.

description:
Best hand pulled noodles I've had since living in China. Authentic to the max. Super nice and very quaint. Great spot to rest in a touristy and busy part of town. I felt like I was back in school in China at a tea house. Nothing better than sitting for hours, slowly drinking great puer tea and ordering snacks when I get hungry. Seriously best hand pulled noodles in the states - which was not expected. Been hunting for these noodles for like 6 years and of course they turn up where I least expected them. Only critique is legs didn't quite fit under the table - because I am tall not fat, I hope. 

Do yourself a favor - ignore the tourist traps around this place and get a bowl of hand pulled noodles and relax with some tea. It's totes in right now.

If you don't know, now you know.
author: Jeremy G.

description:
My boyfriend and I were looking for a place for a quick lunch in the middle of the week, and we found the Imperial Tea Court after wandering around the Ferry Building. It's a pretty tiny spot, but charming, so we stopped in for a bite. There was only one family eating so we had no problem getting a table.

Our server was nice and it didn't take long for me to decide on what I wanted - I went with the spicy beef noodle soup with the house made noodles, which the waiter said are made fresh every morning. There are multiple heat levels to choose from so I went with "spicy," which was one level below the highest heat. Service was fast and my bowl of soup came pretty quickly, and I knew I was in for a test when I saw how red the broth was.

Sure enough, that soup was HOT. The flavors of the broth were very good - luckily the soup wasn't so spicy that it lost any distinct  flavors - and the heat was the type that builds the more you eat it, but I had mixed feelings about the noodles. They weren't round, fat noodles like I've had at places like Shan Dong in Oakland, but were flat and looked like they'd been cut roughly and haphazardly. They were also not very tender, but a bit tough, and a lot of the chunks of meat were very fatty, though cooked perfectly otherwise.

I wasn't as satisfied with my meal as I was hoping, given that for around $12 or $13 I got very few noodles that were tough and a lot of fatty meat. I thought everything tasted good overall, but it wasn't worth a special trip and I'm not dying to return. The iced jasmine tea was a bright spot in the meal, however, so I'd recommend getting one of those with your food, they're very refreshing. But otherwise, I probably wouldn't make the trek over here again anytime soon.
author: Angela M.

description: The staff was so rude we didn't even stay to eat. It looked like it might have been good but their staff has much to learn about customer service.
author: Stephanie D.

description: The pork bbq buns are amazing. I got the teahouse noodles with pork, good price for a nice portion of food, and the pork is seasoned perfectly. And although not a traditional Chinese tea, the Earl Grey with lavender is awesome. Great service, Joy was a great server! Thanks!
author: Luke C.

description:
I don't understand the bad reviews for this place. I've been coming for years and never had an unpleasant experience yet! Today I met with a friend and we had the most delightful, relaxing time. Service is great and unobtrusive. Although it was crowded, it was also quiet, peaceful and they never rushed us.

We both had the stew, beef for my friend pork for me. I'm a big eater but still couldn't finish it. Lots of pieces of pork belly (fat) plus pork chunks in a soy sauce/five spice gravy with rice and tender broccoli .If you get the combo it comes with tea (even iced with a free refill), egg rolls and almond cookies. I had hibiscus iced tea...really refreshing and naturally sweet. Everything was delicious!

It may be pricey but so is Samovar. Considering we got a little 2 hour mini vacation from the hustle and bustle, I'd say it's worth it!

Dim sum and tea spiced pumpkin seeds are also a good bet!
author: Kristy O.

description:
Tea: Good
Service: in between awful and horrible (also slightly awkward)
Dim Sum: Good
author: Dan A.

description:
Located inside the Ferry Building, they set up a table just outside their space during farmer's market to sell some of their wares.

Their Jasmine Iced Tea is fragrant, refreshing, and wonderful!

The Hibiscus Ice Tea is also a good buy.

The Tea Soaked Eggs are so good. Weird but good!!!! Try it!
author: Kislev A.

description: Imperial Tea Court has a variety of teas one can choose from. I ordered a green tea to go and was recommended a green tea with a buttery taste. I have never gone this route with my green tea, but an employee insisted this was her favorite and that it was a must for me to try. Glad I took her advice, the tea was good and I tried something different.  I'll try this place a few more times and will update my review accordingly.
author: Christina M.

description: The teahouse spicy (thin) noodles are AMAZINGLY delicious! I get the veggie option and it's spicy yumminess. The chilies taste deliciously roasted and I love the veggies(mostly cabbage) and soup. The thin noodles are very good but I only wish it was more soup then noodles. They sell the chili oil in jars and it's very very good to add to everything stir fry I've made at home. I've tried the dim sum which isn't as good, but the dessert buns and homemade cookies are delicious. I really just come back for the spicy teahouse noodles, and can't wait to go back soon to get them again and again!
author: Elizabeth R.

description: Nice quite place to have tea,..and not just ordinary tea,... Chose basic to beyond.   They have individual teas or tea blends to make your day special!
author: Plantgarden D.

description:
My friend and I were walking around the Ferry Building and decided to give this place a shot. This place knows their tea. We both got a pot (it's $3 extra if you want to share a pot but we decided to try two flavors) and some shu mai and shrimp dumplings as snacks.

So this place is not your typical tea place. They take their tea seriously. We got two pots because we thought we could just pour each other a cup of the other person's tea ... false. So your tea leaves are actually served in an individual cup. They do this whole fancy thing where they rinse out the first wash and then let you sniff your leaves so you can get the fragrance and everything. Then because my friend had a specialty tea and I had a green tea, we were given water of different temperatures as to not mess up the ... tea simmering process I guess. And then when you sip, you really have to sip. If you're a tea gulper, you'll struggle because basically you use the cup lid as a strainer for your tea. 

How was my tea served at some very specific temperature? Good I guess. It was tea... and without really knowing tea, it's hard for me to tell you if it was good or bad. It was probably on the better side, or I hope it was because it was expensive???

Basically what I'm saying is if you really understand tea, you might have a finer appreciation for this place. But my friend and I really do not know our stuff so we were plebians in this world. I literally didn't even know what green tea to order because they were all the same to me. If you gave me a blind taste test, I'm pretty sure I wouldn't have been able to tell the difference.

The appetizers were not terrible but definitely not worth the money. The shu mai was interesting because they had bamboo pieces inside it giving it some extra flavor to mix up the usual pork grind. Shrimp dumplings tasted close enough to authentic to me but clearly weren't. The sizes are also tiny!! i wish I had pictures but even though you're given six pieces, each bite is super super tiny. 

Total for two pots of tea and two dim sum dishes was about $30. As my friend says, it's kind of one of those places that overcharges based on the premise of authenticity. The tea is probably super authentic, but the dim sum is alright but leaning to mediocre. Atmosphere is nice though and if you're looking for a place to sit and talk with a friend, I'd recommend it.

tldr; good place to hang out and take a break if you're in the ferry building, but unless you have a huge appreciation/understanding for tea, it might be hard to fully appreciate this place
author: Jasmine X.

description:
These people do not know what the fuck they are doing with the gong fu cha tea ceremony. It's $12/person, the service was awkward, the waitress told me twice that she didn't know what she was doing (spoiler alert she did not). Please go somewhere else if you give even a shit about tea being a pleasant experience. If you are the owner or employee of this place please help your servers.

They did have very pretty teawares. The tea itself is quality, and available online. Pretty menus.

When I asked the price of a teapot, the lady read me the info off the website, making no attempt to point them out, while the teapots in question loomed behind her like the ghosts of my dashed hopes for this place. 

I read about this place in the "The Agony of the Leaves"; helen gustaferson are u ok?? This place was bad.
author: Ben D.

description:
Came in for tea and was exceptionally excited. Gourmet tea and dim sum all in one place. My friends also wanted tea but preferred a different food choice next door. 

When they showed to order tea they were sent away rudely and told there was no outside food allowed. 

Although I give the food and tea a five star rating, I was quite put off by both the rudeness of this one waiter and the unfortunate policy that cost this establish the three other tea sales and our future business. 

Unfortunate, but I did enjoy the tea. Too bad I will not be back.
author: Patricia N.

description:
Day 1: had the hand-pulled noodle soup w beef and broccoli. Ate alone.
Day 2: came back the very next day with 5 coworkers, had the the hand-pulled noodle soup w beef and broccoli... ah with cabbage this time!

Best noodle soup I've ever had. The noodles are made same day at the shop. What a difference from their packaged counterparts. The cubed beef is also very tender. For you vegetarians, you can get the same with just veggies.

The ambience is beautiful w lanterns, decor, and dark wood furniture.

The people are wonderful too.
author: Ryan M.

description: Refused to serve me BBQ Pork Buns togo at 6:14pm when they closed at 6:30pm. Claimed the cooks had thrown out the water to steam the buns. Poor excuse as water is readily available and easy to heat up.
author: Tim C.

description: Must try their sui mai selection and beef hand-pulled noodles! The lychee iced tea is soooo good.
author: Fanny T.

description:
After a hard day of volunteering, I came here to eat some food. I'd never been here before, but first off, it looks beautiful in here and the seating looks cozy but actually isn't. I picked noodles, not realizing it would be a noodle soup. This is not a dish I usually order Thankfully, it was extremely tasty, and I finished it right away. But it was probably because I was super hungry...I didn't really get a lot of meat in my noodle soup, but that's okay. I got no beef with that. (nyuk nyuk)

I happened to be in the area again and this time tried the pork over rice. Erm...that was not a pleasant experience. The pork was 98% fat and 2% actual meat. Erp. My stomach turned when I saw that. Definitely not pleasant. Essentially, I ended up only eating the tiny pieces of meat that were a part of the dish and the rice. It was not very filling and it made me a bit sad.

Next time, I may try their teas, but food-wise, meh.
author: Robbin A.

description: If you like salt, please be my guest and dine here. I did not enjoy the food here. It was a bit pricey and not good. Sui Mai was so tiny and even trader joes Sui Mai tasted better. Thank god it only cost $6. Anymore my wallet might be crying. The beef stew was tender but way too much sodium. It's stew so it's been sitting and absorbing all that sauce. Sadly, I will not be returning. Perhaps the spicy noodles is a better choice If you ever decide to dine here.
author: Ann L.

description:
Really loved this little gem in the Ferry building. We had the shrimp dumplings, which were little mini dumplings, hand stretched noodles (we made them very spicy and enjoyed them a lot while clearing our sinuses), and the baked vegetable rolls. We didn't miss that they were not fried. 

The teas are the best part, of course. Highly recommend the lychee black tea and the ginseng tea. Not bitter at all and very smooth and fragrant! The server also showed us how to traditionally brew and pour the tea! Great service!
author: Sara A.

description: I ordered the Fresh Hand-Stretched Beef Noodles which comes in a spicy broth.  The Beef was very tender and delicious and the flat noodles were very soft (I can't explain the noodles but let's just say they were mushy.  It's good, but I couldn't eat much of the noodles, I was more interested in the Beef then the soup.  About the soup, very oily, although I wouldn't mind coming back to try their other dishes on the menu.
author: Joane B.

description:
I am a huge Asian food lover. Literally all Asian food. I was very excited to see this vendor, saw such a long line, and had very high hopes. Sad to say my expectation led to disappointments. 

I ordered a spring roll and my friend ordered the veggie bun. They were both very hot and I added soy sauce and chili. Both our foods were too salty and with the heat combined, did not let us completely savor the food. We couldn't even take more than two bites from our food because the salt level was beyond our taste buds. I had higher expectations and Ferry building definitely needs to step up their Asian food game.
author: Gladys L.

description: Stephanie C, seriously did you even order anything? I don't think you did. I think you just ordered water. I'm sooo sorry that you had to get up and get your own water, even though there are only two people on the floor at all times. Really get off your high horse and calm the hell down, because this whole woe is me act your trying to pull off of getting your own water is not cute, honey.
author: Rayven W.

description:
The wide selection of teas make it worth a trip to try over lunch.  You may want to consult the staff for a recommendation.  Oolong, dragon well and green tea are common selections.  However, the prices has increased and it becomes tedious trying to share even with the extra fee for doing so.  Therefore, the staff encourages that each person get a pot of tea that they barely finish unless you sit there for hours.  Unfortunately, it becomes arduous to pour the water into a bowl and then hold the cap while you pour the bowl into your cup.  

The food is okay.  Nothing special.  The best dish is their signature spicy noodle soup with the Niman ranch beef, which is a bit too lean for the flavor of the fat to meld with each bite.  The Beijing style braised beef, which lacks flavor, is again too lean and not tender enough.  

Service is slow and sometimes friendly.  The ambiance is a traditional tea house in terms of furniture, but the feel of a private tea place is missing.  Parking is tough on the street unless you find spots in nearby garages.
author: Jenny L.

description: I was craving for some beef noodle soup, so my boyfriend and I dropped by their Ferry Building location after work on a weekday. Their website says that their restaurant closes at 7 while kitchen closes at 6:30, so we made sure that we arrive around 6:10. However, even arriving at 6:10, the waiter was really reluctant to seat us, and was really pushing us on ordering fast. On to the food, they only had vegetable buns, so we got a couple of those, a couple of tea eggs, and tried out their beef noodle soup. I would pass on the tea eggs. They lack the "tea" flavor that's essential, and seemed like it was only being seeped for a short amount of time. I ordered my beef noodle soup on mild while my boyfriend got it with medium spicy. Let me say, they're definitely on the spicy side. So I would recommend lowering a level of spiciness if you're ordering. We got their hand cut noodle. Being Chinese and growing up with really good hand cut noodle, their noodle was not super great. The width of the noodles are very inconsistent, and the it's on the more dough-y side. Overall, 3/5, not super special.
author: Sharon L.

description:
To recuperate from the arduous daily demands of a hectic lifestyle and to clear one's mind, one tends to get to a point where a slow pace is imperative once in a while. Imperial Tea Court is where I headed one day I needed a slow pace to enjoy a nice cup of tea, to seek temporary respite from the insanity that is the year-end of a fiscal year, and to send off a close friend. The first mission was accomplished, while the last two were not entirely accomplished.

We asked for gong fu tea service, as we wanted to have a beautiful experience. The dining room is beautifully decorated, and the hustle and bustle of the Ferry Building seemed as if it were a block or two away, so my friend and I got to having the wonderful conversation that the place seemed to demand of us. When our server returned, he patiently described what he was doing and why (e.g. pouring hot water on the stoneware for two reasons: to warm it up so the tea would be warmer longer as a cold stoneware would "steal" heat from the water, and to wash it and sanitize it which was established by the ancient Chinese who did not have the luxury of our running water and/or dishwasher). The puerh tea had a very pleasant earthy flavor and my friend and I resumed our conversation while drinking our tea.

Here is what irked us and simply prevented us from enjoying a leisurely tête-à-tête: the other server seemed determined to turn us away ASAP. When our first pot was empty, he promised to bring us more hot water, which took at least ten minutes to arrive. Once he gave us our second pot of hot water, he asked us if we could pay our bill already because they were closing (this was around 5:45, 45 minutes before their advertised closing time of 6:30). It was abrupt and, quite frankly, rude, but no problem...we were not planning to add anything to our order, anyway. What truly got to us was being asked to leave at around 5:55 because they were closing. My friend and I were displeased. We thought we had another half an hour so we were delaying the goodbyes. Now we have five minutes to say our "I will miss you's" and let me tell you, that is not a very pleasant thing to do. There was another couple there in the restaurant eating their meal, and they were rushed as well.

What became apparent to us was that this server seemed to be in a rush to go to a gig. There was a bass resting against the wall when we arrived that he was moving just as we stood up. Oh, and yes, we were told to be careful not to ruin his precious bass (admittedly, this could have been a failed attempt at humor but at this point we already considered him a rude server with minimal customer service skills, so really we are a bit biased already). 

I am not sure if I would go back. Maybe if I did, it would be to have some tea with no expectations of a pleasant time spent there.
author: Clarice O.

description: I loved this place!!! The pork buns were GREAT but I would skip most of the dumplings -just doesn't do Chinese dumplings justice. Great tea selection. I loved the flavored ginger ales.
author: X O.

description:
Really good tea, ok dim sum.  I got the dim sum platter, and wasn't really impressed.  If I were you, I'd sit at the front table where you can take off your shoes and sit Japanese style, order some tea, and people watch.

And if you want dim sum, go to Chinatown.  It's a short Muni ride away.

http://sexydishes.blogspot.com/2011/07/please-take-off-your-shoes.html
author: Vira P.

description:
I came here with Rachel E. and I'm not surprised to see that she and I give Imperial Tea Court the same rating.

I agree that the service was poor. Not only did our waitress disappear after serving our food, she had a piss-poor attitude the entire time she interacted with us. Our questions were met with a mixture of condescension and surliness, and I don't think she smiled once. I'm fine with this kind of attitude in real Chinese restaurants, where prices are dirt cheap and food is abundant. But not for a place like this, where a small platter of disgusting, barely warmed-over dim sum costs a whopping $12. Seriously--I tried one of Rachel's shu mais with the knowledge that it was filled with either pork or vegetables (she'd requested both), and I literally could not tell what the filling was made of. It was just greyish mush. You know it's bad when you can't tell if something is pork or veggies.

My order--the signature spicy noodles--was certainly better, but still unsatisfying for the price ($12). The noodles were slightly overcooked, the broth was a tad too salty, and the diced beef was surprisingly pungent (not a good thing). However, it was a bowl of hot noodles and soup, and on a chilly March afternoon, it more or less hit the spot. For tea, I got the Purple Bamboo green tea, which was bland and poorly steeped. If you're expected to pay $5-8 for a small cup of tea, I think you should have the option to steep your own tea. We were not given that choice, and our waitress clearly had no idea what she was doing.

The tea room/restaurant is rather nice-looking, with its dark, cherry wood, ornate carvings, shelves of shiny tea-ware and jars of loose leaf teas. Just don't look at anything too closely, otherwise you might notice all the dirty, exposed ceiling pipes, the chipped wood and the unclean floor. 

I don't doubt that there is some level of sincere tea love at Imperial Tea Court (the owner does, after all, sponsor the annual SF International Tea Festival). But to me, the whole place screams "attempt to cash in on wealthy patrons who can afford to shop/dine at the Ferry Building but don't know enough about Chinese tea culture to tell the difference between Imperial's over-the-top, 'exotic' Chinese-ness and real Chinese tea rooms". One need only look at the mediocre, overpriced food and bland, overpriced tea. I've been wondering why this place only has 3 stars on Yelp when it looks so good from the pictures. Now I know why.
author: Josephine L.

description:
We were at the Ferry Building for the Good Food Awards this past weekend and decided to get lunch here. We had been to the Imperial Tea Court in Berkeley before and really enjoyed our food, so we thought coming to this location would be a safe choice. However, we were disappointed to see that the dishes we had tried before at the other ITC were not listed on the menu since they only offer a limited selection.

What we ordered:
-Vegetarian teahouse spicy noodles ($12): shredded cabbage, carrots, mushrooms, and noodles in spicy broth http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/imperial-tea-court-san-francisco-2?select=FnIwo4X2TGKbgpQq5xIS3g#a2Yq-Gi6dt2dhZn76qOQYA
-Wontons in jasmine tea broth ($10): organic pork wontons in jasmine tea broth http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/imperial-tea-court-san-francisco-2?select=FnIwo4X2TGKbgpQq5xIS3g#lTtahp_xQKGrn91dnMpPtQ

We also picked up a passionfruit ginger ale drink right outside the storefront for $3 since they were selling them, but you can also order it off the menu after you sit down (http://www.yelp.com/biz_photos/imperial-tea-court-san-francisco-2?select=FnIwo4X2TGKbgpQq5xIS3g#FnIwo4X2TGKbgpQq5xIS3g). The ginger ale was amazing and this is coming from someone who doesn't usually drink ginger ale! The ginger flavor was subtle and not too strong while the passionfruit added a refreshingly fruity taste. 

I was surprised when the spicy noodles came out since the portion size was a good amount bigger than that of the wonton soup. The noodles and veggies were good, but the broth was VERY spicy and definitely was too much for me especially since the hotness of the soup also added to the spiciness. I didn't finish the broth, but the part I did drink actually made the top of my lips hurt a little after :( I heard that the wontons were tasty but that the jasmine broth was a bit light. This was fixed though by taking some of my spicy broth to give it more flavor.

Service was prettyyy slow too because there were only two women working. We must have waited 10 minutes for our check to be processed and it felt like we practically had to beg them to take our money! This was slightly annoying. Overall, okay food with meh service (but they are hiring, so maybe it will improve in the future).

TIP: Go to the Berkeley location instead for higher quality food and a pretty outdoor seating area!
author: Jessica C.

description:
Odd.   Had a great tea from them last weekend.  Called so I could order more, and the person answering the phone didnt have the information.   She was kind enough to connect me with the guy in charge, and he just laughed at me.   Told me the tea was nothing special. 

Ok guys, i got the hint.  Will go elsewhere.   Good luck.
author: Johnny C.

description:
This tea shop offers the standard Chinese style, if you are a little pressed on time (or a little lazy) to make it to Chinatown.  A wide diverse selection of tea was a nice surprise, though some confusion in ordering as we didn't quite get the teas we ordered.  The quality of the tea was lower than you'd expect from the prices you pay (15$ for a tiny serving of a dragonwell that tastes stale??)

Food was good, a little pricey, but to be expected in Ferry Building.  

Service was good, though the majority of the tables were not occupied.
author: James O.

description:
This is a review of their pork buns (the $5 ones).  

I was playing tourist at the Ferry Building on a Saturday and walked by Imperial Tea Court.  They were selling buns at the front of the restaurant.  I bought a BBQ pork bun on an impulse and it changed my life.  It was AMAZING!!!  Best pork buns ever!  (And I'm not even exaggerating).  

Seemed a little pricey at the time, but I would go back and pay $5 for more.
author: Sumin S.

description: Come back again for Teahouse spice noodle with Pork and Veggie and a Gaiwan cup of my favorite Oolong tea - Gui Fei Cha.
author: Yui D.

description: one of the best steamed char siu bao ive had and not because of the filling which was good but the bao. don't know how they were able to get it so soft and light. squeezing it was unlike any bao before and would be easy to eat one after another and another.
author: NYSD G.

description:
I came here on a Saturday afternoon at about 3 pm. Its located within the Ferry building so its rather touristy, but the tourists had dissipated by the time we arrived for our tea. 

Once we arrived we were seated immediately. Once seated, we waited about 20 minutes until the lady that seated us came by to take our order. In fact, we had to flag her down in frustration. Once our order was taken, which was just two orders of tea, we waited about 20 more minutes. We were very frustrated and asked her how much longer until our tea would be ready and she seemed to have forgotten that we ordered tea. Maybe she thought we just came there to sit around an empty table without water or napkins? Our tea came out 5 minutes later. In conclusion, come here if you want decent tea, terrible service and are prepared to wait 45 minutes for tea. 

TEA IS GOOD + SERVICE IS TERRIBLE = ME NOT COMING BACK
author: Reena P.

description: Whenever I am in the city, I stop by the Ferry Building to enjoy some great dim sum and wonderful tea.  I love the chrysanthemum tea - fresh flower brewed right in front of you.  The service is always impeccable and very attentive.  Not many places have chrysanthemum tea but it's great for the digestive system and love, love, love the light aroma.  I love the dim sum! - it is much better than in Chinatown and it's not Chinatown, so that's a big plus.  :)  This is a wonderful place to "take a break" from the hustle and bustle of the city.
author: Jolyn S.

description:
I met up with a friend here on Friday for lunch. We were seated right away and enjoyed the peaceful atmosphere. It's a pretty space with a wall full of tea and just a few tables. 

I ordered the dim sum sampler, my friend ordered the spicy noodles. Our food took a while to come out which was ok because we were having a leisurely lunch, but this is definitely not a place to go in a hurry. I checked my phone and it was literally 25 minutes from the time we ordered. My dim sum plate came out way before the noodles. I would definitely suggest sharing everything here so you don't have to awkwardly wait to start eating.

I only had a bite of the spicy noodles, but they were pretty good. Definitely spicy! My friend seemed happy with those. I guess that's their signature dish and maybe I should not have deviated from it.

My dim sum was ok but for $12 it was small, and I think yank sing is better across the board.
- Pork shao mais were the best thing on the plate
- The vegetable steam bun was the worst

We did not see our waitress after she delivered our food. A different guy cleared our table and brought the bill. I ran out of dipping sauce part way through my lunch but didn't see anyone to flag down.

We each ordered some tea but the tea menu did not have any prices, and I was VERY surprised when our bill came to find out my cup of tea was $8. Yikes! It was delicious tea though.

Overall this was 2.5 stars, but mostly because of the nice atmosphere I'm rounding to 3.
author: Rachel E.

description:
Good service! They come by often to check on us, both before we ordered and afterwards to check on the temperature of the water.

When our tea came out, they showed us how to "drink" the tea using their special Chinese tea cups - they have lids that let you hold back the loose leaves while drinking out of the cup. It's cute, but also kind of kitchy. I've done real tea ceremonies in China & Japan and never seen anyone use cups like these.

I had the lotus hearts green tea. It has the slight bitter/dry taste of any green tea - the leaves are cool, they are thin and long and float vertically at the surface of the water. It lasted several cups of tea but then I had to pee like a racehorse (be wary - the Ferry Building bathroom is almost at the other end of the building!).
author: Ziyan C.

description:
I felt like I stepped into a wuxia film set when I came in.  The decor, lighting, and even the mugginess of the room felt about 10 minutes from being the restaurant fight sequence of a movie.

As a precaution to my infamously bad food allergies I ordered a vegetarian dim sum sampler plate and rose garden tea.  The egg roll portion of my meal wasn't my favorite.  I was surprised I liked the rice dumpling so much.  It was literally just wild rice in a wrapper.  Also a siopao/bao/bun filled with Chinese mustard greens.  It was bitter without ruining my palette for the day.  Freaking amazing.

The tea I selected (rose) was appropriately flowery and light.  lt was refreshing without being overpowering.

Things That Were Not So Awesome:
---Muggy.  A friend argued this makes this a more authentic Asian restaurant experience.  I don't know.  I was honestly a touch uncomfortable.
---Bland?  Well, I didn't find it bland personally.  It's not super spiced or anything like that.  It's 'imperial' style, which has a more delicate finish than your standard Chinese fare.
---Overpriced.  Well you are a fool to think you're getting a bargain meal anywhere near the Embarcadero or the Marketplace.  I found it to be reasonable for the area we were in.
author: Christine L.

description:
I purchased a Chinese tea set for my 16 year old daughter and some wonderful jasmine tea. The young man selling really was very helpful
And helped me choose one that would last a lifetime for her. She absolutely loved it.
author: David B.

description: I am not a huge tea fan, and just came because of my wife.  The tea house does look quite authentic, with a huge menu of fresh teas to choose from.  The way the tea is served is very authentic, poured into a tin bowl to allow the drinker to smell the fresh brewed tea, the leaves are poured into the cup and hot water is added continuously when drinking as each taste becomes more flavorful.  We ordered the tea sampler, which came with delicious cookies and pumpkin seeds to go with your tea.  They also serve various dim sum items for those that want something savory.
author: Christopher F.

description:
Walking through the marketplace at the Ferry Building, there is tons to see and even more to taste.  When my lady friend spotted the tea eggs she loves, we had to pull over to give them a try.

We got a tea egg and also a red bean bun.  We both agreed that neither of them were really up to par and the eggs not cooked properly and were especially difficult to peel and eat.  The bun was just so-so and at $5 for the lot, it was a pretty expensive bite.

While the shop itself was full of folks sampling expensive teas, the "tapas" were pretty disappointing.  They weren't horrible, but didn't have the authentic flavors I'd expect.  Service was meh too so overall it was a very 3-star experience at best.

Food: 5/10

Service: 6/10

Price: $$

Atmosphere: 7/10
author: Joe M.

description:
This was a nice quiet spot in the midst of the busy Ferry Building on a Sunday afternoon. We stopped here for some tea and a bite to eat because it looked like a place where we might quickly get food, since everywhere else looked so busy.

The servers were all nice, although ours was SUPER quiet. We could barely hear him talk. The food also took a while to come out for the place being so empty. We decided on 4 or 5 of the dim sum dishes, which unfortunately ended up being enough for maybe one  moderately-hungry person, and we were two VERY hungry people. The slow service didn't help, and the food overall was kind of bland. So I suggest not coming here for the food, although the entrees may have been better--it looked like the few groups of people around us were getting those.

The tea was good though! We got some of the Genmai Cha tea, which is a DELICIOUS green tea with toasted rice that overwhelms the flavor deliciously. They taught us how to pour the tea which was really cool, and we ended up walking away with a 1/4 pound bag for 11.25, which to me is decently priced. We're still enjoying the tea today and I'm glad we checked this place out to find it--I'd tried that tea a while ago and just couldn't figure out what kind it was, so it was great to find it here!
author: Katie V.

description:
I love this place! 

They have an extensive tea menu and take the time to let you sample their teas until you find the one you want. The hand-stretched noodles are so delicious (try them spicy with vegetarian toppings), and the teahouse spicy noodles are also wonderful. The BBQ pork buns are a scrumptious treat, too!

We found the service to be excellent. The servers were present and available but did not interrupt us as we ate. I'll stop here every time I'm near the Ferry Building!
author: Heather S.

description:
Honest, the beef noodle soup reminded me so much of the way they make them in Taiwan that I spent the next week looking for something similar in the restaurants closer to me. But, that was pretty much the only positive part about my experience here. I came with a friend around 2:45PM for a late lunch, and the first thing we noticed was that there was no service. Now, I've been to China and Taiwan multiple times before, and while I've had "bad service", I've never had service as bad as what I got here. The waitress consistently ignored us, and when we had to call her over, she would make it obvious that she thought she was better than us and didn't want to wait on us at all.

We ordered the Afternoon Tea Dimsum Sampler with the Earl Grey & Lavender Tea and a spicy beef noodle soup. We were not informed that the Tea Sampler came with only one cup of tea, and when we tried to ask for another cup so that you know, we could split the tea between the two of us, the waitress refused and said that the afternoon sampler only came with one cup. Umm...Okay. I don't see the big deal of giving another cup so that 2 people can share tea, unless you really expected one person to drink an entire teapot's worth of tea. Dimsum sampler tasted stale but authentic. Is that an oxymoron? The tea was good.

When the waitress came out with our food, she immediately set down a bill on our table. I don't think I've ever been to a restaurant like this that charged premium prices but was also rude enough to bring out the receipt so quickly. My friend and I took a look at the receipt though, and immediately noticed that it was not ours. We called over what seemed to be the head manager (white guy who worked more the store side), and he quickly fixed the mistake. Apparently it was meant for the lady at the table right next to us. Umm..

In the end our total came out to approximately $30. The beef noodle soup was yums, but everything else was okay. Until they train their waitresses better though, I don't think I want to come here again. Serious, even the waitresses at the divey Chinese restaurants in Chinatown treat me better...even when they discover I'm not an authentic Chinese and speak poor Chinese.

To be fair though, the white guy was the epitome of customer service, and he was who we had to turn to all the time. He even super eager split our bill between two credit cards just so that it would be more convenient. I feel bad for the guy, holding the fort down and compensating for the rest of his staff's rudeness.
author: Melody L.

description:
I don't know what I was thinking - getting dim sum in the middle of a crowded marketplace at a restaurant clearly too clean/fancy to fit in with the rest of the dim sum restaurants in SF (let alone: the world).

The bread was uneven but had close to optimal fluffiness. The savory pork inside was a totally different story. Not totally sure what they're using to season it. They smelled great but had virtually no flavor. I left disappointed and cursing my foolishness - $3 poorer and a heart filled with hangry sadness.
author: Merlyn D.

description:
I'm so glad we stopped in here despite the bad yelp reviews. Tea service was awesome! I've never had tea served in such a manner. The server went step by step with us regarding the whole process and was patient in helping each of us select our own special teas.
 
Everything was novel to us, even though we have had many a cup of tea. Who knew drinking tea was so complex? I love things that require ceremony! It makes you take time and appreciate whatever it is you are doing. 

He began with rinsing the tea with an initial wash of water to remove the tannins so it was not so bitter. He drained the water through a flying saucer type contraption before pouring in some fresh water to have our tea steeped and served. 

It was a really cool learning and cultural experience and since we only had tea and no snacks it was relatively inexpensive experience.
author: Oulie T.

description:
Saw the Bao in the steam basket in front, and decided to purchase.

Waited for a while to be helped, but found the steamed bun for $3.00 to be worth it based on quality/taste.

I think this is one of the most memorable bbq pork buns I've had.
author: Richard H.

description: I ordered a few fresh pork buns to-go, while I was walking through the Ferry Building.  Perfectly cooked, seasoned and fluffy.  For $2 a piece, I thought they were a great snack.
author: Heath C.

description: All we can say is, Read the description of a few ingredients in the steamed vegan buns.  It'll lead you to think they're in the bun.  There will only be one of three ingredients, though, when you take one bite.  Or, when you pull it completely apart.  This happens again and again.  The latest  experience was the greens, tofu, mushroom vegan bun.  It had greens only.  First, the manager tried to excuse it by saying, "Everything's chopped so finely that you can't see it."  Okay, so why can't you taste them?  Another priceless comment of no accountability, "Sometimes one bun will miss the ingredients because of the way the dough is laid out."  We handed her the torn-open bun and requested a refund.  She said sorry once and ignored out repeated request for refund.  In fact, she turned her body away and shrugged her shoulders.  Finally, I'm listening to other folks, who have been taken for a ride here...or shall we say, for a fraudulent bite?  There are many other spots in the Ferry Building to grab a good nosh; and you'll get what you pay for, with management's pride in quality and accountability.
author: Paula H.

description:
Food wasn't bad, but the service was HORRIBLE. 

They have a very extensive tea list, but the service is HORRIBLE

Prices aren't bad, but the service is HORRIBLE. 

Don't think we will ever go back.
author: Cody H.

description:
I've been here three times and each time I'm pleasantly surprised though each time this is not my chosen destination. Why, I wondered....so I believe it's the layout of the place.
