It's too open to the ferry crowds walking by and it seems crowded. When I think about tea...I want more mellow. Give me more mellow...;-)

I really enjoy the vegetarian dim sum. It's not incredible but it's tasty and includes a nice assortment. A restaurant generally gets some extra points from  me if they have a specific entree, or more, for vegetarians. I don't mind ordering side dishes but at least I know they thought about us and wanted to accommodate.

If I could I would rate this restaurant 3.5 stars because the tea service could be so much better, especially considering the price they charge. I'm spoiled...I've had traditional tea in Japan and Hong Kong...and in the SF Bay area we have some very lovely tea houses (Samovar, for one). I'd like a little more attention paid to the tea service and perhaps it could include a small, lovely sweet that might entice me to order dessert?
author: Leslie K.

description:
Pleasant refuge in the busy Ferry Building.  The staff is nice and helps you select and drink the tea properly and the server helped rinse the tea leaves before brewing.   They have small dishes and cookies to go with the tea.   

I haven't had their noodles or other dishes as meals though, but would like to try that next.
author: Dan C.

description: I decided to buy a freshly steamed bbq pork bun to go, and it tasted like any bbq pork bun from most dim sum restaurants I've been to. It wasn't bad or great. It costs 3 bucks for one and for that price I expected it to be outstanding. Service was just so so too. I could probably buy a bag of bbq pork buns from Ranch 99 or any Asian market for 4-5 bucks, then steam it myself. A better deal and will taste pretty much the same.
author: Kosmo Z.

description:
Date & Time:  Sunday April 26, 2009 @ 2pm
Location:  Ferry Building Shop 27
Company:  Michael
Crowd:  Foodie Couples of All-Ages & Young Families w/ Bugaboo Strollers
Atmosphere:  Zen
Decor:  Traditional Chinese Tea House.  Lanterns.  Redwood Tables & Chairs for Quatre
Service:  Courteous & Polite
Imbibe:  Tea
Devour:  Spicy Beef Noodle Soup
Mediocre:  The Dim Sum Sampler which Consists of 4 Bite-Size Sui Mais, 2 Har Gows, 1 Egg Roll, 1 Mini Chicken Bun & 1 Red Bean Bao 
Total:  $30.29
author: Genevieve Y.

description: Traditional tea place with variety of tea. They also serve dim sum and other small entrees. Very unique!
author: L Y.

description:
Wow, they've really got some great people working on the descriptions of those menu items.  Everything sounded over-the-top fantastic on the menu.

Take the Dragon Well dumplings for example.  The description on the menu: "Handmade dumplings filled with Niman Ranch ground pork shoulder and infused with Imperial Tea court's dragon well green tea."  Wow.  Sounds amazing, right?  Well, these were just alright.  Plain ol' pork dumplings that were kinda small.  They were savory.  The skin wasn't that thick, but not thin enough that they fell apart.  Big whoop.  They didn't taste remarkably better than any other place.

I had the Teahouse Spicy Noodles with pork. They were good. Satisfying if you want something warm.  The noodles were on the thin and soft side. The pork was ground up. Interestingly, the server offered me the option of "spicy" versus "not-spicy" for this dish.  Hmm... but it already says spicy in the name...?  Anyway, if you get it non-spicy, the broth is less oily.  I think they use chili oil to spice it up.  Overall a good dish, but not spectacular.  

I suppose you'd be coming here for the tea, rather than the food.  There was quite a large selection of tea.  I got something with ginger and ginseng.  My partner got black lychee (which smelled way better than mine).  The tea is loose, and it comes in a little cup with a lid and a saucer.  There is a pot of hot water on the table. You're supposed to pour the water into this cup, wait for it to brew.  The difficult part comes when you're supposed to pour the tea from this cup into another cup for drinking.  The table just ends up getting wet.  Or you could just sip from the original cup.  

I can't comment on the authenticity of this little tea ceremony.  I've never seen tea served this way in Chinese culture.  Or Japanese culture... or ... whatever.
Anyway, this was a fun little experience.  Not for the food per se.  Maybe for the tea, but definitely for the lounging-factor and the people-watching.  I came here on a Saturday, and was able to avoid the massive crowds from the Farmer's Market.
author: Jeanne L.

description: I passed by this tea store while at the Ferry Plaza Farmer's Market and noticed that they had lychee tea on their menu, so I ordered an iced lychee tea to try. Wowza, that was some good lychee tea, the best I've ever had. I bought a quarter of a pound (for $11) to bring home with me and now I'm wishing I'd gotten more, but it was pricey. If you like high quality teas, definitely check this place out.
author: Terri D.

description: Like the other reviews state: the service was terrible. Extremely slow and kind of awkward. According to the wife and brother in law, the tea was okay. The spring rolls were alright but took forever to come out. Ended up spending $34 for two spring rolls and two teas. WTF?
author: Izzat A.

description: Pork bun was sub-par and cost $3.  Kind of a ripoff.  Probably wouldn't come back here.
author: Letitia L.

description: Loved the hand pulled noodles! I had the vegetarian one and it was spicy, flavorful and delicious. The noodles were chewy and nice. The portions were large and very filling. I'd stop by again for lunch.
author: Maddy K.

description: I had a Groupon for one Tea Presentation and Tasting for two, so it was a perfect place for my good friend and I to catch up.  Loved the tea presentation, smelling the different teas and drinking up our tea tastings along with our dim sum sampler and additional shrimp dumplings - yummy!  Loved it, I'll be back!
author: Maile N.

description:
Okay, I didn't try any of the tea.  The ginger ale tastes pretty good, but leaves a strong burning sensation on your throat.  Definitely not a good thing.

Worst of all though is the expensive price for the less than mediocre food.  The whole set up might occasionally catch a tourist off guard, but I'm not fooled and was definitely not impressed.  My friends and I were the only ones there, but it still took almost half a hour for our orders to come out.  The spicy noodle was okay, but the noodles were definitely store bought and not hand made.  The steam pork buns was a good size, but the pork inside was about the size of a dime.  Skimpy.  But as if this wasn't bad enough, we also got their shrimp dumplings.  Had to bring out magnifying glasses to see those six little "dumplings" on the plate.  

Expensive with nothing to show for it.  This business model definitely will not last.
author: Michael L.

description:
OH YEAH!!!

Came here over Pride weekend and found this little gem in the Ferry Building.

INCREDIBLE shrimp dumplings and TO DIE FOR tea-infused hard boiled eggs.

Normally, we go to Yank Sing for dim sum, dumplings and tea, but I have to say that this place came incredibly close to YS's quality.

Servers were knowledgeable, very sweet and responsive.

We will be back next time we are in SF.
author: EzBein G.

description:
Not sure why this place isn't ranked higher. Maybe the location is held against it?

Regardless, I stopped in for a quick bite after seeing dragon well dumplings on the menu (DRAGON WELL DUMPLINGS!) and savored every bite. Pair it with some tea, and maybe throw in a couple steamed buns and enjoy.
author: Phil C.

description: This place is a gem!!! My friend and I each got the prix fixe (tea, egg roll, entree and cookies). For tea we got Wild Tree Aged Puerh and Chrysanthemum. Entrees were spicy noodles and lamb dumplings. Every single item was absolutely amazing. The dark earthy puerh went so well with the broth and lamb dumplings. I will be coming back to try every single item. How is this place not packed???
author: Nick L.

description:
lovely place to take a break from the "busi"-ness;  and with a good cup of tea to help one savor and relax, cosmic.

There lies the problem.  The first time I got a cup of osmanthus green tea, the tea server was not only helpful, she brewed the PERFECT cup of tea.   The second time I went there for exactly the same thing, hoping to capture the perfectness of the first...the cup of tea was tastless, and still overpriced.

I will give this place another try and hope the quality returns.
author: Li Y.

description:
Tea is excellent and I like the art it get served and explained. The tables are a little bit too low for my legs, I am 6 foot 3.....
The spicy noodle soup was great, will go there again.
author: Andre S.

description: Horrible service.  We were not greeted when we enter which was probably a sign that we should have just walked away, but after we went all the way to the back, we finally asked someone for a table since they didn't offer one.  We ordered chicken dumplings and when I bit into it I could tell it wasn't chicken, it turned out to be lamb (which I don't eat for personal reasons and have never had in my life until that day) and when we told them about it they were very unapologetic and didn't seemed to think anything was wrong. Not only that but when I bit into the dumpling a TON of oil squirted out (gross!) I'm never going back.
author: Tasha K.

description:
The Imperial Tea Court is in the heart of the Ferry Building, next to a shop that sells only mushrooms, and a shop that sells really great Gingersnap cookies (Miette's).

But the Imperial Tea Court does tea: teas of all kinds, teas from all places, and etc. It's ok. And pricy. 

Here's the deal. The tea is expensive, but good. Very good, and it comes in a host of selections. The ice tea is good, but even more overpriced. The food is not so good. Considering that if you're at the Imperial Tea Court, you're only a few handfuls of blocks from one of the most rich ChinaTowns in the United States, the food is less than not good. It tastes of tourist trap. Even during "Happy Hour," or esp during.

Come for the Gaiwan and Gong Fu tea presentations, avoid the food, and then buy some mushrooms. Or skip all of that, and do it someplace else in town for half the price and all the flavor.
author: Liuyin S.

description:
The place has a nice ambiance and a welcoming staff. Our food came out rather quickly and our water glasses never went empty.

The food itself, was surprisingly good. I ordered a chicken curry dish which set me back $15. I would argue that the food is pricey for lunch. Considering the dish was only big enough for one person and that I've spent less than $15 on chicken curry at other places (and was provided with enough curry to share with multiple people). The food wasn't  good enough to warrant that price tag. 


Good lunch spot to try, but not amazing enough to make you want to be a regular.
author: Abena O.

description:
I was there for lunch today, it was my second visit.  The first time was tea, fun to people watch, lovely teas to choose from, but slow (that was ok).

Today was pretty bad.  I agree with Cody and Josephine below.  HORRIBLE service.  Really.  There was only one other table taken when we started.  Still, we had to seek out the wait-people both times - to order, and later to get the bill.  They just seem not to keep track of time or to care about people who come in to eat.  Food was so-so.  It is not worth the money, and I really think they could take a lesson in being timely (and friendly).
author: Mari A.

description: Their teas are pretty good but service was horrible. The woman working moved us to another table and then told us to leave so she could seat other people. Rude!
author: JY H.

description:
A tea house that's obviously for the Gaijins.
Went there a few weeks ago as part of our quest to cover every eatery @ the Ferry Plaza.
I was extremely suspicious at first.
Dim Sum sampler was a pleasant surprise.
Each pc of little morsel has a home made feel to it (shrimp in the hargow a bit dry yet still fresh and tasty)
No traces of MSG as far as I can tell which got me in awe and wonder.
That itself deserves 4 stars or more.
Hope they dont get taken out of business by the 1 Ferry Dim Sum restaurant just opened close by.
author: avalon e.

description: Do yourself a favor and get a marbled egg with a side of hot sauce. You won't be disappointed.
author: Cat C.

description:
Come here for the tea! The food and tea snacks are optional. Some are excellent, others not so much.

But here it is about the -tea-, with many fine selections, and all served in the Chinese style. Oolongs are particularly good (some of the high mountain selections are excellent) and all of the teas seem fresh. Gong fu style service available.

This is a place to drink tea, a seemingly simple act, but one full of Zen implications.
author: Mark S.

description: Purchased a Pur Erh to go my fav and a bag of Natural Rooibos to bring home with me.
author: Flyinlow ..

description:
Did someone say "tea time"? =)

This is a cute tea shop in the middle of the ferry building. Totally unexpected amongst the shops of meat, cheese and olive oil. You're definitely going to need some tea to break up some of that stuff in your body. =P

They offer a plethera of teas ranging from $5 to $8 each. A little on the pricey side. If you want something light and slightly sweet, their premium white tea with rose petals isn't bad. But it is a premium tea for $8. But you can get it in a prix fixe menu they offer for $20 that comes with a spring roll, choice of tea ($3 additional for premium tea), choice of entree and cookies. Also a little steep but a good deal if you're looking for food AND tea. 

there are a bunch of food goodies to munch on here. When I was here I went for their spicy noodle soup ($12). You can get it with a choice of beef, pork or vegetarian. Of course, the carnivorous me when for the beef. MMM. Cow good. They say they use some high grade stuff. The beef was super tender. The broth had good flavor and felt light. The spiciness was pretty good but I could have gone for some more heat! =)

I also tried my boy's braised pork shoulder with rice ($15). YUM. So tender with just the right amout of fat! The sauce is slightly sweet and tastes great with the rice. The flavor was on the light side but you wouldn't want the sauce to be overwhelming. 

If you're looking for something lighter they also have dim sum and snacks, but I didn't get to try these. 

Overall, pretty cool tea house to stop by at least one time while you're visiting the ferry building. But with those prices, I'm not sure I would be stopping by too frequently. But definitely worth a try!
author: Daisy T.

description:
Wow - what a rip off!  We had a Groupon for a tea sampler for  two and were joined by friends. We knew in advance that our friends would have to pay $15ea, 
but thought it would be fun and that it would be paired with tastings of a bit of food as well.     $15 each turned out to be ridiculously overpriced for the small amount of tea we were served.  The info given about the tea (we were allowed to choose 4 teas from 6 possibilities) was minimal at best.  I can't believe they have the hutzpah to charge this for so little... We won't return.
author: Jean S.

description:
We stopped in for a quick bite on Saturday afternoon while wandering the shops at the Ferry building.    First time here and what lured us in was a big menu board in front of the restaurant with several menu specials and photos.   They all looked delicious and the descriptions sounded over the top amazing.

Stupid me...  what a red flag !!   This place is a total tourist trap if there ever was one !

I can't comment on the tea as we didn't order any, but we did have the Dim Sum sampler and a side order of broccoli which came to about $20 or so. 

Bar none, this was the worst dim sum we have ever had.    All of the it seemed pre-made and frozen and just reheated in the microwave or toaster oven.   I suspected it was either from Trader Joes or Costco.   It was really, really bad.  It had that distinctly freezer to microwave "chewy on the outside and soggy on the inside" texture.  Totally gross, but we were starving and we choked it down.   

Sure enough a couple days later while at Trader Joes I was in the frozen food isle and low and behold there they were ... the pork buns, dumplings, and egg rolls !   Even the frozen broccoli florets !!

So.... I don't know what to say beyond that.... perhaps they have good tea.... but we surely will not be back here again to try some.

There are so many great places to eat in San Francisco, this is not one of them.
author: Alan D.

description:
Lots of high end and pricey teas.  I think you could do better at tea houses in China Town or even Japan town.  This place is really more for tourists who stop by the Ferry Building.  The best thing about this place is the location (in the Ferry building).  The workers here call themselves tea nerds, but they did not look or sound like tea experts at all - and the tea talk they gave was meh.  I got the ginger ginseng blend and let me tell you - there was no ginger or ginseng in it at all - it tasted more strongly of chamomile.  I also think it is pretty lame that they don't offer a tea strainer so your leaves just sit in your tea, and for certain blends, that means it gets stronger and more bitter over time.  My friend had the prosperity blend and the hibiscus was just over the top.   Do yourself and your pocket book a favor by finding a real tea house in Chinatown or Japan town.

The food here is meh also.  It's pretty lackluster - but remember that the main feature here is the tea.  This place is clean and they do serve decent (but not the best I've had) tea so it's 3 stars/average.  Giving them 2 stars would just be harsh, and they are clearly not 4 stars.
author: Bebe W.

description:
Service is the worst experience ever. asian woman are as rude as can get, the token white guy (looked sort of out of place) was normal and seemed actually service oriented, buth the women act like they are doing you a favor, only redeeming item on the menu is actually the tea, try the lychee, very nice and so fragrant and the noodles, everything else is subpar and a waste of your money.  

with that said, nothing is worth coming back here to endure the service, attitude, and lack of energy in the place.
author: J P.

description:
As much as I LOVE tea, I didn't get to try it here - sadface. Maybe one day. 

I came here with a coworker for lunch - thought this place looked cutely Asian. The wait wasn't long at all, which was nice considering all the other food places in the Ferry building had long lines. We decided to share two plates: dim sum sampler + spicy beef noodles. 

I had a feeling the dim sum sampler would be a disappointment as this wasn't a dim sum restaurant. But I was hopeful. The sampler came with siomai, shrimp dumplings, pork buns, and baked spring rolls.

I was right - the dim sum sampler kinda sucked. Decent, but definitely DO NOT come here for dim sum. It's just not worth it. 

What surprised both of us though was how DELICIOUS their spicy noodle soup was. Like surprisingly flavorful, authentic, and hearty. Yummmm! The broth had a perfect kick to it - spicy, but nicely subtle. I wouldn't even add more spicy sauce in it (which I do often to my food). The noodles and beef were perfection. This soup is perfection!

So really, I'd just come here again for their spicy noodle soup (which won my heart over). I feel like this place is my new little secret.
author: Stephanie B.

description:
Don't waste your time!!  

I love every merchant and store in the Ferry Building.  I'm here every week and am always excited by the produce, food, tourists etc.  I decided to try the tea at Imperial Court... got the Lychee tea... and asked the server at the stand by the entrance who was serving, if it was sweetened.  She said it was naturally sweetened...  so I paid the $3 for my tea drink... it was so sour and so bitter.. so I walked inside to the restaurant.. There was nobody inside... the woman behind the counter was super rude... I asked her for some sweetener... she barely acknowledged me... continued wiping down a counter and said... they didn't have it...  she said only suger and walked away...Seriously?  It's a tea house... no sweetener and shocking rude service..  I found the only bad place in the ferry building.... Will not go back there.
author: Billy B.

description:
Smell the tea!...SMELL THE TEA!

The server will insist you do so, for it will soothe your soul with the elixir of Confucius. OK, they don't make that big a ta-dah of it, but I think they should do a show here like Teatro Zinzanni and have a female impersonator play Shanghai Lil with her fishnet beret and mysterious manner. She could go around singing "Slow Boat to China" with a Marlene Dietrich accent and pour arsenic in our tea cups from her golden dragon ring. They provide the opium den decor with the expensive-looking Chinese chairs, tables and room arches.

I have to admit I was rather confused as to what to do when I entered...go to the counter to order?...grab a table and  hope for a server with a menu?...whisper government secrets to the waitress that will ensure Chinese political and economic domination of the world and bring the Bush administration to its knees? I went for the table...and waited...and waited. I think the Cultural Revolution was over with by the time she came.

I decided I needed to go authentic so I went for the Gaiwan Tea Presentation, which amounted to a big pot of hot water, a covered tea cup, the above mentioned smell test and specific instructions on how to drink the tea...I felt like I was attending a special school for the tea leaf-challenged...perhaps making me a candidate for the Special Olympics if I could stop throwing a ball like a girl.

Steep (and steeped...ba-dum-bum) at $5 for the presentation, the premium Imperial Silver Needle Jasmine has a soothing delicate flavor, nothing like a Lipton's tea bag. Since I was rather peckish, I also went for the $6 Snack Sampler, a plate of four types of nuts...imperial spice raisins, roasted almonds, green tea pumpkin seeds, and my personal favorite, the green tea walnuts. Yeah, it was bird seed, but it seem to fit. If they served hot food, it was not readily apparent. If you ever want to live out a Pearl Buck novel, this may be just the place for you.

TEA and NUTS - 4 stars...flavorful in that oh-so-exotic way, a bit pricey
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...Charlie Chan went that-away!
SERVICE - 2.5 stars...quietly zen about their tea and really slow
TOTAL - 3 stars...Shanghai Lily has a message for you..."You just missed your ferry, Mac"
author: Ed U.

description:
Tea and snacks break at the Ferry Building, mmm...
Nice tea selection, well-brewed and pleasant surroundings.
author: Anna J.

description:
Tea leaves picked by monkeys and balls that explode into beautiful flowers are some of the many rarities this shop sells on their extensive tea list.  Though the teas are plentiful and exotic, the food menu is quite limited and mundane.  As a tea shop, it probably deserves 4 stars.  As a restaurant, which it poses as with the many tables, it does not rank as high.    

Teahouse Noodles w/ Pork: Loads of spicy ground pork mixed with small cubes of carrots that almost disintegrate in your mouth because they've been cooking so long.  The noodles are thin like angel hair spaghetti.  The broth is subtle and sparse.  I felt like this was halfway between soup and a noodle dish (in a bad way) since the broth was barely there.  Pretty bland despite using their "famous" hot sauce.  I normally don't even mention price, but will deviate this time because it is way out of parity at $13.14 for this one take-away item!
author: Adam B.

description: Tea is roughly about 8-10 dollars a person. They have lots of the asian snack foods like dumplings, buns, and some noodle dishes but if you come here, you are usually coming here for the tea. I had the imperial oolong, my friend had another type of oolong, and a third friend got a white tea. Flavors were aromatic and enjoyable, they brought out fresh hot water when we were low and we spent about two hours talking about drinking very good tea.
author: Steve Y.

description:
I was tired and hungry after a chaotic hour at the Saturday Farmer's Market and decided to check out some of the places in the Ferry Building. The lychee black iced tea sounded intriguing and made me want to try the food at the Imperial Tea Court.

The dim sum sampler seemed like the right amount of food for a single diner. I grew up eating dim sum at my very own family restaurant so I am admittedly a dim sum snob. The dim sum at Imperial Tea was not exactly traditional, but it was tasty. I really liked about 50% of the sampler. The rest were ok and there was one I hated. The one I hated was the red bean steamed bun. I hate red bean and would have preferred one of the other fillings. Some of the other dumplings seemed a little bland (have we not heard of salt?) but the ingredients were interesting.

The service needs some work. It took forever for me to get my check and it took awhile to place an order. By the time I sat down, the restaurant wasn't very busy, so I don't really understand where the spaciness from the server came from. Other diners seemed to have similar problems.

I would definitely come back for the tea, and I would probably try one of the other dishes before passing final judgment on the food.
author: Dani D.

description:
Tea: Great tea selection.  I haven't seen this large of a selection for authentic Chinese tea in the city (not including Chinatown).  

Atmosphere: peaceful, elegant.  This place also plays soothing Chinese music that complements tea tasting well.  

Food: didn't try the dim sum here.  But I  wouldn't come here for dim sum if that's what I want to eat.  The selection didnt seem very good.  I am a fan of the spicy beef noodle soup (you might want to ask to add some vegetables in the soup b/c apparently the choices of vegetable and meat are mutually exclusive)
author: Rosa L.

description:
My husband and I were doing the touristy thing. I wanted to come here for some Dim Sum since I've walked past this place many a time when I visited the Ferry Building

The servers were nice and acommodating.

We ordered the dim sum platter:
Sui Mai - small but very delicious
hargow - good flavor
Steamed Pork Buns - small but succulent
Baked Vegetable Rolls - tasted fried, but they were excellent and filled with a great amount of veggies

Dragon Dumplings with shoulder pork and tea dipping sauce -husband loved these steamed meat dumplings and stated they were excellent

We drank lychee iced tea.


Minus one star because they didn't come back to check in on us, but they seemed really busy.

We will be back

I love good dim sum and I know you can find a good hearty and fatter dumpling on Clement Street at Good luck dim sum. But I really don't trust chinatown since I really don't know if I am eating cat or not. And I'm sorry, I don't want to get food poisoning either.
author: Charlene C.

description:
Pumpkin Seeds are nice, and green tea walnuts.  Prices are ok, but $5.00 for a cup of tea is sort of high, even for SF. Nice tea selection.

It used to be nicer there, a few years ago.  Service is only acceptable. 

Rosebud tea by the lbs to go is fine.
author: Abigail J. M. M.

description:
This place was good, but very specific.  It is a tea place.  They also serve food, so that you can have food with your tea.  For lunch, they have a handful of selections, and two are vegetarian, which made me glad.  I ordered the vegetarian curry tofu and was worried it would be spicy, but it wasn't.  It was overpriced, as most ferry building food is.  ($11.00 or $11.50 included tea, but the food itself was like the $4.95 lunch special at a cheap Thai place, so that's a $6 cup of tea if you subtract the difference.)  But I was pleased with it, and the tofu was surprisingly filling, or maybe just the tea made me not hungry later (I'm not used to having any caffeine).  

There were a billion kinds of tea to choose from.  Well, maybe like 35 kinds.  They had romantic sounding descriptions.  Mine was called Misty Island or something like that.  Instead of just slapping the tea down in front of us, we each got to look at our tea leaves, and the other's tea leaves, and then the waitress poured a little hot water, and we each got to sniff both.  I tried to drink the tea the way the waitress demonstrated, but it wasn't easy, felt awkward.  I definitely ate some tea leaves!  But that was cool.

I think this is a good place if you want to have a long conversation with someone and linger (but not during the busy lunchtime).  I also think it's a good place to bring a tourist.  If you don't want a meal, you can have cookies.  Or just tea.  This is the kind of place I would rather go than a bar, because you can drink and talk and linger and stuff without the nasty smells and rude behaviors that bars have.  Of course, this is not a nightlife place but a daytime place.  It could also be cozier.  For two people to sit at a table, your companion is a bit far away, more so than usual.
author: Stacey B.

description:
I had Yunnan Mao Feng green tea. Others with me had Monkey-Picked Ti Quan Yin, Misty Mountain, and Silver Needle Jasmine.

Even here, with a statement on the menu about using a temperature around 150 for green tea, they brew it too hot. :( The leaves are very good, though.
author: Chris E.

description: Food choices are limited and very over-priced here. If you have to choose from the menu, go with hand-made noodles（手拉面）. They are decedent. Their tea selections look impressive, but I never tried. Most likely they would be overpriced too just because of the location.
author: Emmy P.

description:
To start, I've never had the food.  If I wanted dim sum I definitely wouldn't get it at Ferry Building.  It's about the tea.  I've never seen better tea; the only thing close is Chaikana down in Santa Cruz.  Whether you want a simple black tea blend or top shelf Longjing, I challenge you to find better tea in norcal.

Their Monkey-Picked Tie Guan Yin is always solid: herbal with floral and chocolate notes.  Their Imperial Green ranges from OK to game-changing, still worth checking out each season.  Their oolongs are usually solid.  If you subscribe to their email list, you can keep up on what teas are in season.

Their berkeley location has the same selection but much better ambiance; there's a nice outdoor seating area and you won't have throngs of tourists, though hopefully you can tolerate hippy tea nerds.

Good tea is as complex as fine wine; go here to get educated.
author: s b.

description:
Wait time for noodles: 33 mins. They admitted that they forgot about me and gave me a discount on my tea.

The imperial green tea was pretty good. I had beef spicy noodles that had huge chunks of beef and tasted... beefy. The spicy levels did not disappoint because it was enough to make sweat pour nonstop from my forehead, neck, and occiput (medical term FTW). I needed more napkins and hair gel. The lunch was mediocre, and I'm not so sure if this was worth the long wait. If I'm going to pay $8 for tea (-$3 for the "I forgot you" discount) and wait 33 mins for $12 noodles, they better be the best friggin' tea and noodles I ever had.

The decor is nice and the staff is friendly and knowledgeable. Too bad their service is unacceptably slow.
author: LM M.

description:
Outside of being a serious authority on every aspect of Chinese teas, I never would've guessed that this little shop would serve up lunch too.   The menu is limited and I wasn't too fond of their dim sum (I must be too accustomed to grease), but their spicy beef noodles are downright delicious.  Kind of "la mian" style, though I'm not sure if they really are homemade noodles or not.  Likely, not.  But still, the noodles were surprisingly good. 

All of the teas are served in prettily patterned gaiwan cups, where the lid of the cup serves as a filter for tea leaves while you're drinking.  Ooh, a little complex, but fun.  And it's even more fun to lean back in your chair and stroke your pretend scraggly white beard, all the while sipping a gaiwan full of the highest quality Dragonwell.  Or, um, maybe that's just me.
author: Joanne G.

description:
I don't know if it was the interesting tea that I tried here or just the cold ambiance.  This place is basically like a tasting room at a wine cellar, but lacking the alcohol.  There's no real warmth to this place and you sit on hard wooden chairs.  Its very chinese I guess and the tea does have an interesting affect.  

If you are looking for a wide variety of teas then this is definitely the place to go, must be a tea lover though, not just a visitor.
author: Ronjini M.

description: Best meal so far in SF.... The spicy noodles were amazing, servers were sweet and engaging. Lots of great teas.
author: Scott L.

description:
We stopped here for lunch, a very pleasant space in the Ferry Building. I chose a green tea that I had not previously experienced from a long list of such teas on offer. The covered tea cup was also strange to me but OK once the waitress showed me how to use it. The spicy noodles, pot stickers and other finger foods all had unusual flavors which I liked.

Second Opinion: Lana was unimpressed and would rate the shop at three stars.
author: Lana G.

description: Pleasantly surprised by the food.  I fully expected to get really awful touristy Chinese food (Chinese food in the Ferry Building, and at a teahouse as opposed to a restaurant - what was I thinking?) Instead, the food was actually really good.  I ordered the wonton in tea broth.  Not that much of a fan of the broth which tasted like seaweed in water, but there were a generous number of wontons and they were good.  As advertised, the wonton skin was relatively thin, which is how it should be.  My boyfriend had the spicy teanoodles with beef and he really enjoyed it.  I also had a jasmine oolong tea which the server instructed me to drink in a certain way, but it wasn't anything special.  There were probably 50 varieties so next time I will pick something a little more unique.  Servers were really not in any rush, as others have mentioned.
author: Vivian W.

description:
I generally like this place.  I love their spicy noodles and they have a great tea selection (as they should since they are a tea house), but the last time I went there, it was a bit of a disappointment.  The noodles weren't spicy, the egg rolls were cold, the service was off, and at the end of it all, I was a little less in love...er, like with this place.  

When they're on top of their game, however, their spicy noodles are the bomb.
author: Renee D.

description:
I was drawn here for the same reasons described below: busy summer weekend and I had to get lunch. Plus I needed to sit down because I had a toddler with me. Despite person-to-person packed crowding, this place was empty.

There were two other tables with people at them.  Yet it took the two servers 15 minutes to take my order. 30 minutes later, I asked where our food was.  Somehow they sent it to the wrong table (which they told me after 10 minutes of fidgeting around).  I said I would just pay for the tea (I had seen the food come to the other tables and it didn't look good and people did not look happy). 15 minutes after asking for my check for the tea, I left some money on the table and left.  And this all is when there were only three people in this place.

The servers generally gave me a creepy feeling.
author: Christopher V.

description:
This post is for the Rose Garden Tea - subtle, calming, good for all times of the day (early morning tea, mid-day treat, rainy night comfort) and amazingly fragrant.  It's also one of the more affordable teas in their selection.

It was good bait...can't wait to go back and try more!
author: Sarah Z.

description:
I'm not a great tea drinker so it might seem strange for me to end up at Imperial Tea Court.

However, I was seduced by their dim sum sampler. Travelling on my own, if I have dim sum at a normal restaurant, I don't get to eat many dishes but this seemed ideal - a collection of a smaller number of dim sum dishes. So I sat down and ordered the cheapest tea and the dim sum

Unfortunately, the dim sum was only of average quality and a let down for the Ferry Building. Nice variety but the flavours were a bit muted - adjusted for western palates maybe?

Never mind, I was soon feeling happy again, wandering through the Ferry Building smelling truffles and tasting olive oil
author: Yee Gan O.

description:
The Imperial Tea Court is a very zen version of a wine bar. So many different varieties  to choose from, and the subtilties in each variety happens after you acquire a taste for tea. 

I ordered Rose Dragonwell tea, which was served in a traditional tea cup. Tea leaves are placed into the cup and the lid of the tea cup is angled slightly to keep the tea leaves away when you are sipping tea. I kept stopping to breathe in the rose essence...its so fragrant and soothing. 

I ordered the dim sum sampler dish which included hargow, shu mai, meat dumplings and a meat bun. They all tasted very home made and delicious. 

Its great that its tucked away in the Ferry Building and definitely worth going to if you're in the mood for some light dim sum (it means touch the heart in cantonese) and you want to stay away from the usual dimsum crowd.
author: Susan V.

description:
didn't have time for tea tasting so bought one to drink and teas for later brewing . ..

+ : good teas . .. nice ambiance . .. nice selection of teas . ..

rose bud tea was ok, and not the best around:
lychee blossom tea . .. good:

-- :  water in my tea was "not pure", tasted like tap water (came as quite a shock since the quality of the water is quite important to the overall experience) . ..
author: Y I L I W.

description: I had lunch with two friends and we had noodles, stew, dim sum, and tea. The bill was $75. The tea was odd if you like it that way. The soup was a mishmash of flavors. It just seems like the price was way larger than the food warranted. The setting is beautiful and that is a good thing. Too bad the food doesn't match.
author: gabrielle h.

description:
I went with a friend from Taiwan, and had a wonderful time!  The wait staff was surprisingly knowledgeable.  We sampled a fujian tea that wasn't on the menu, suggested to us by our server.  We also got a variety of seafood dumplings, red bean paste dumplings, and a green tea wonton soup.  All our dim sum was delicious, and the diminutive sizes kept us from filling up too much.  My Taiwanese friend felt that all the fare was pretty authentic.

The Tea Court is both a tea accessory store and a restaurant, which unfortunately impinges on the ambiance of the place.  The restaurant would be much better if it was in a space with windows onto the street or the pier.  The decor is tasteful, not the usual red and gold palate found in Chinese restaurants.  Definitely a place I will visit again.
author: Phaedrus E.

description:
I always thought this was just a place that sold tea, until a friend took me here for lunch last week. 

We both got the spicy beef noodles and iced hibiscus tea. The noodles were delicious! (Note to those that can't handle spice, just ask for it w/as little spice as possible, still tastes great) The tea was okay. I'm guessing it probably would have been better hot. 

Regardless, the Court gets 3 stars because I thought $12 was kinda pricey for soup and the service was ridiculously slow. We sat there for at least 20 minutes before a server approached us, we never got water - even after we ordered - and we had to approach the server ourselves to get the check. So, if you've got time for a looooong lunch, this place is a fine choice. Otherwise, I'd opt for one of the other Ferry Building options.
author: Kate P.

description: I came here because one of our friend was really into tea and he wanted to show us that we can taste teas from all over asia and when u r drinking these teas, there are actually rules that u have to follow. Who would have guess it?? Anyway i love teas but this guy make teas very tiring to listen to after a few sampling. I didn't get to try the food because this idiot keep talking lol....
author: John N.

description:
My friend and I wish we never stepped foot in here. Nice decor...and that's about it. Overpriced, tiny portions, inane service, and food took entirely too long. Being asian myself and having made dim sum, shumai, etc, I know how long it should take. The restaurant was small, maybe 3 tables had guests that already had food, yet our order took over half an hour to get, most of which we didn't even order. My friend has an aversion to mushrooms which is why we asked to substitute certain items from the dim sum sampler for more shrimp dumplings. The server seemed as if she understood, but when the food finally arrived it wasn't what we had ordered. It was double orders of the most mediocre and sorry dumplings and dim sum I've ever had the misfortune of having to eat. Her seemingly broken English, combined with her thievery, bamboozled my wallet. What should've been a $12 light lunch so we could go to other places to eat turned into a $40 crappy meal. We left most of it on the plate. Absolutely awful. Do yourself a favor and walk faster when you encounter this place. Godawful. 
PLEASE DO NOT EAT HERE!!! 
And to the owners: YOU ARE DOING CHINESE CUISINE A HUGE DISSERVICE. Your shrimp dumplings and shumai were 1/4 of the size they should've been. Your dough recipe for the steamed buns is wrong.  It's like all you did was go to chinatown for nice decorations and thought that would be enough to run a restaurant. So sad. You ruined my lunch.
author: jacki l.

description:
Dim sum sampler - very tasty and light. I am usually not a fan of the red bean pastry, but this one was very good. The savory dumplings had very light skins and the egg roll was crispy. 

The tea is excellent, which you would expect and warming on a cold SF day. 

Seating - what the heck is the matter with these tables. The table side bar hits you mid thigh. Either lower the chair, raise the table, or get rid of the bar.
author: A I.

description: Go for the tea and enjoy the experience.  We went to the original location for years and always enjoyed it.  Never ate, just drank phenomenal tea.  Their black lychee and white chrysanthemum Mint teas are fantastic, especially together.
author: Ottis M.

description: Pricey, but tasty dim sum and tea.  The spicy noodles with pork was a very good lunch.
author: Kev M.

description:
I visit any tea house I see and this one was alright. It's true what other people say about the ambiance. It's kind of cold, open and sterile, they could create a more intimate eating area, surround it with more plants, etc..

I had lavender green tea a pot. I wasn't really into the tea so when they guy working asked me how it was I hinted to him that I would like to try something else. He hesitated and stalled clearly not wanting to give me new pot. oh well. The tea got slightly better after that. It was an ok experience.
author: Sarah A.

description:
Really, this is another argument for being able to give half-stars.  I really liked the Imperial Tea Court at the Ferry Building location because of its ambience -- quiet, not overcrowded, vaguely Zen.  Now I must admit that I am not the world's foremost fan of tea, but the tea we had, the 2009 Organic Purple Bamboo tea (?), pretty much had an imperceptible taste, which outweighed the interesting spiel we got about it and the guidance on the tea ritual and how it is drunk (out of a little tiny refillable pot, holding the lid so that there's only a small crack for the tea to flow through so that you don't get any of the leaves in your mouth).  Had it been a really great tea, I would feel much differently, since this is their selling point, but even my lunch companion, who is a tea person, was not impressed.

I also got the "dim sum sampler," and although it had types of dim sum I had never seen before, it also consisted of very miniature versions of common dim sum.  Again, sort of the same story -- very nice and elegant presentation, but the substance was not to rave about.

Conclusion:  probably a great place for a quiet conversation if you are a tea aficionado and find a tea you like there.  And I do like that it's a little patch of quiet in what can be an intense atmosphere amidst the chic consumerism of the other businesses there,  But it would not be among my first choices of places to revisit.  2.5 stars.  PS:  it's also on the expensive side.
author: moosedog i.

description: I'm not a particular fan of the food here, especially when in such close proximity to Chinatown. However, they do have a vast selection of teas-- some varieties which you can only get at an Asian tea shop. Two stars does not reflect on quality of the actual tea, but only because there are definitely better options in the San Francisco area.
author: Frances L.

description: Came and had a simple lunch here.  We ordered the tea leave duck soup with noodle.  It was really oily and we couldn't get much of the tea flavor out from the soup.  Meh...not impressed.
author: LeeLee C.

description: I really did want to like this place - it's cute, the decor is very nice, and they have a huge tea selection.  I came in before a noon meeting to kill some time in the Ferry Building and ordered one of their more popular green teas and the BBQ pork bun (which was recommended by the staff).  First, I need to say that the amount of tea provided is ridiculous.  They must have given it to me in a 20 oz. container - WAY too big for hot, green tea.  That should really come out in a few ounce cup.  The tea was good, but the volume was just baffling.  Had I just ordered tea, this place may have earned a three star rating, but I ordered the BBQ pork bun...  The BBQ pork itself was actually good, but the bun was so thick that the meat-to-bun ratio was around 3-or-4:1.  I had entire mouthfuls of food with no pork in it because of how thick the bun was.
author: Matthew K.

description:
Definitely overpriced and geared to tourists who don't mind paying a lot for a little.  The $5 tea was tasteless; I have better tea at home that was purchased at Ten Ren on Grant Avenue.
The shrimp dumplings and pork dumplings were miniatures, about one half the size of those served in other tea houses.  At twice the price.
author: el h.

description:
2007 is the new sobriety is the new intoxication.  It's true.  I have not had a drop of alcohol since the middle of December. . .actually, the last sip of alcohol I had was just that, a sip (or maybe two but they were teeny tiny) and it was some incredibly expensive, sophisticated herbal, aged, dark colored spirit.  I don't recall it's name - it was special and I know that much because someone had to travel down to some secret cave to a special locked room to fetch the bottle that was sealed with wax.  

This is a review about tea I know. . .

Since my decision to see what life is like sans alcohol, I've started getting to know tea.  I'm more of a coffee (delicately crafted cappuccino thank you!) type of lady.  I never gave tea a chance because I love my cappuccinos.  There was no room for tea in my life before. . .you see, I had my wine (spicy Zinfandel, deep Chenin Blanc, port old port --- the memory of a delicate Riedel glass with finger prints on it, evidence of a dinner party enjoyed brings a tear to my eye. . .sniff), I had cappuccino's, I had water.  Now that I am not drinking alcohol, it's opened up a spot for tea.  

In my quest to find "my tea", I decided to check out Imperial Tea Court at the Ferry Plaza.  I'm not crazy about the layout.   It feels crowded to me, which might be okay if all the tables and chairs weren't so hard.  I enjoyed my tea, and have been back for tea to go.  Regarding the ambiance and layout, I would check out the original for the real Imperial experience.  

On to the tea. . .the low down. . .

I got the Organic Dragonwell for a friend in Amsterdam who is crazy about tea.  He enjoyed it and thought it was pleasant.  

I've tried the following:

-Genmai Cha --- very good.
-Organic Gunpowder - ordered entirely based on the name.  It was good.  
-Ginger Ginseng Green Tea - I can honestly say I felt like Superwoman after drinking this tea.  Wow.  Experiencing something like this is what I mean when I say that "sobriety is the new intoxication"  Give up alcohol for two months and then go have a couple cups of this stuff and get back to me.

Aside from the fact that the Ginger Ginseng Green tea made me feel like putting glitter on my face and hopping a red-eye to go back in time to dance all night at the Tunnel NYC with six-inch vinyl thigh-high platform boot wearing drag queens on mirror paneled columns in the middle of a dancefloor that has a suspiciously white hue (phew!), the tea is all very nice.   

I'm a new tea drinker so I don't know all the "tea terms" but I always feel good after drinking tea.  Imperial teas taste good - in my opinion.  I can't tell you if they're better than the other tea places in the city because to me, all fresh/organic tea is pleasant. . .

. . .maybe it's time for a real tea tasting. . .to be continued!
author: James M.

description: After perusing the Saturday farmers' market, we went into the ferry building to see what was there... we were delighted to see vegan red bean dumplings and vegan spring rolls with lychee iced tea! each item was priced at 3 dollars and the service was fast and efficient. I didn't mind paying the 3 dollars for the appetizers because they were big and it takes a lot of work to make dumplings and rolls! It was exactly what we needed for a little break.
author: Linh N.

description: My rating is on the noodle soups. The spicy brisket is really good. I love coming here on a cool day for some soup. I havent tried their tea or any thing else on the menu. Generally its a little pricey, but the soups are worth it.
author: Huy T.

description: Tea was wonderful. But the Beijing stew was full of fat and gristle.  I complained to the old lady who was serving me.  She did not apologize and tried to justify it, saying that it was organic. Organic does not mean inedible!  Avoid the beef ! Yuck!
author: Stephen L.

description:
Contrary to the opinion of some of my friends I *do* drink more than just fermented grape juice.  Witness my frequent visits to the Imperial Tea Court.

Now I fully admit I am a tea novice.  This place makes it fun to be a novice!  Why, you ask?  Well, I'll tell you - I have a list:

1.  Looonnnnggg menu, subdivided and annotated and practically indexed.

2.  Friendly, helpful waitstaff.  Oh, and patient - very very very patient.

3.  Unusual ways of serving the tea (in other words, very non-western and therefore unique for me)

4.  Good food.  Oh come on Suzanne - great food!  How often do you find enough on the menu to have a substantial lunch at a tea house?  If they are serving it, try the pork 'stew'.  Yum.  And yes, there are veggie options on the menu.

5.  Cool space.  If you want to be quiet head for the back, if you want to people watch and absorb the energy of the Ferry Building, sit right up front.

6.  Teapots everywhere!  

And they - oops, forgot one:

7.  Good tea!
author: Suzanne B.

description:
THEY GET IT!!!!!!!!!!  :)))) 

You ask for spicy food and they bring you spicy food! They don't look at you like you're from some other planet or a bizarre creature!! 

So, when I dug into my noodle soup and slurped up the broth......the chemistry was hard to miss. The spice opened the doors of my cell membranes and instantly promoted a sense of well being :)

I love the decor, especially when you get to squat and eat.
author: Me Iz S.

description:
i have never had bad service here.  it can be on the slowish side sometimes, but you are in a teahouse.  it's all about taking your time for tea.  it's a bit pricey, but you are in the ferry building where everything is pricey as it's a tourist spot.

tea is great.  food is great.  especially the spicy noodles.  no complaints.
author: Karen O.

description:
Preet is right on the money.

Their spicy pork noodles are nothing more than glorified overcooked spaghetti with a scant sprinkling of ground meat and barely a hint of scallions. 

Despite being one of the only  two occupied tables in the whole restaurant, I had to wait an inordinate amount of time to get a menu, wait an inordinate amount of time to place my order, wait an inordinate amount of time to get my check, wait an inordinate amount of time to get my change. 

Do not go here for a quick lunch. Do not go here for a satisfying lunch. The Ferry Building is full of great restaurants. This isn't one of them. They should stick to tea.
author: Pamela B.

description:
Actually 3.5 stars. 

My friend and I met here for lunch. No wait and perfect place to chat and catch up. We both got the combo dim sum plate - of course some things were more up my alley than others, but everything was good (with a couple standing out a bit more). Everything came out pretty quickly so we never felt like we had to rush to get out so that we could get back to work. Be both didn't hesitate to say we would come back!
author: Jen N.

description:
UPDATED 5/11/09: Went there today and was NOT impressed. It appears to be under new management and definitely a new chef.  The dim sum are much smaller and look amateurish in appearance.  The texture of the skin was papery and the dipping sauce was not more than hot vinegar with soy sauce added.
-------------------------------------------
I am always confused when someone states that they were overcharged after getting exactly what they were promised.  The ITC is a traditional tea house.  In the midst of the noisy, hyper busy Ferry Building they have somehow created an oasis.  Upon entering you feel and sense the calm.  The selection of teas and the attention to their care and service ranks among the best in the bay.  Rather than inundating the customer with a 100 item menu of so so fare, ITC features a small changing menu of carefully selected and well executed items that complement the teas.

I can not find fault in their restaurant and left feeling that is was money and time well spent.
author: David A.

description:
a high end quality tea shop. 
knowledgeable staff and a nice selection of collectible teapots too.
a great place to sit and sip tea with friends.
too bad I was in a rush this day.
i am learning to appreciate fine teas and the subtle nuances of the different types. this place is a great place to go exploring the full range of offerings from full bodied monkey picked TieGuanYin to a lighter jasmine tea.
author: Jeff W.

description:
Stopped here for lunch and got the Teahouse Spicy Noodles (vegetarian). I had it mild heat, which was perfect for me. I really enjoyed the dish but wished there were more vegetables in the dish. The amount of noodles was perfect & certainly filling. Also had some tea which was a unique experience.  They rinsed the leaves in the cup first to get rid of any contaminates, etc.  She added new water to the cup and explained the process of drinking the tea. You hold the saucer in your palm and with your other hand, hold the lid more perpendicular to the top of the water to hold back the free floating tea leaves so you don't accidentally gulp them down. I had gotten the imperial peony & rose tea. This tea was ok and not as robust as I had hoped for. It was on the light flavor side and probably would have required a very long steep period to be where I would have liked the taste to be. 
Service was good- no complaints there.
author: Tara R.

description:
I love this place. It is so relaxing to be in...a zen, calm environment in the heart of the Ferry Building. 

Ok, so this is first and foremost a TEA place. And they do a pretty good job. The tea selection is amazing -- such an incredible variety of teas. I've been many times, so I've had the sen cha, earl grey, rose petal tea etc, all were very high standard. The presentation is a tradition Chinese gaiwan style, hence the separate tea for each drinker. Fun!You can also visit and just buy tea to have at home, and it seems like that's what a lot of people do. 

I would also recommend the food. The curry chicken is really something else... yum! I haven't had the dim sum platter so I cannot speak to the comments below.

Finally, the service here is inpeccable. He was very attentive, and spends a lot of time explaining about individual teas. I would come back here time and time again.

****

Update: It seems like the server that I really liked there has left. It's a shame, he was the best thing about the place -- such a great knowledge and excellent customer service. The lady that usually works here is the opposite-- extremely rude, pushy and inconsiderate. I would fire her for sure if I was the manager...
author: Sarah F.

description: Sleepy little place for a cup of tea.  Kind of odd that they serve it by the cup.  Got the herbal hibicus tea.  Extremely sweet for a herbal tea.  It's hard to drink hot tea when it;s very warm and there is no AC.
author: Carolyn W.

description:
What a drag. First off, our waitress was either brand new or just s l o w. Or maybe they were just understaffed, badly.

Our iced teas were super sweet and strong to the point of not being able to take more than a sip. The meal was nothing to write home about. As a matter of fact, the spicy noodles that I had were nothing more than noodles in oily broth wtih a few strips of vegetables. And that plus iced tea was $14!? Wasn't worth it.

The best was at the end when we gave her two cards to split the bill with. It was as if we'd asked her to perform brain surgery on the spot. It probably took a solid 30 minutes from the time our check was delivered until we were able to leave the joint. 

There are so many better places to check out to eat there. And if you're looking for tea - go to Chinatown to the Red Blossom Tea House. Much better experience for tea.
author: Christine O.

description:
After 3 days of walking around sitting down for a nice cup tea was VERY relaxing.  This was a great place to do it.

The food is sort of pricey....but looked well prepared.  I liked the atmosphere in the hustle and bustle of this building.
author: Brian M.

description:
This place is shit-tea (pun intended). See below:

I walk in and seat myself.  Two employees are standing at the register but don't notice me right away.  They both seem new to waiting tables/working in a restaurant. Shmeee. No big deal.

Baaaad chair/table combo.  My legs barely fit under the table. I feel like a female version of Andre the Giant.  Freakishly big.  Perhaps I shouldn't be eating lunch at all today.  I probably shouldn't eat until I can actually fit at the table.  I begin to think the employees feel the same. They haven't paid me any attention since I walked in.

Now I just want water.  They serve tea here.  Tea requires water.  Water must exist at this place.  Nope.  Not for freakishly big girls sitting at awkward tables.  Ok. Forget eating here. This thang is taking way too long. I'll just get it to go.  

While I'm waiting for my order, I see the waiter pouring the elusive water out of a Tupperware container.  A Tupperware container at a tea house?  Their designer (or whoever picks out tables/chairs/pitchers) needs to be fired.  Come on!

Twenty minutes later I get my order.  Spicy vegetarian noodles = spaghetti (seriously) with oil, red pepper flakes, and a bit of veggies.  Veggie steam buns = dry tasteless bun, but the veggies were actually tasty.  I won't be back.
author: Nicole K.

description: Convenient location for me since I work 2 blocks away. I was introduced to the North Berkeley location, which is a fantastic location. Jasmine Pearl Tea is the tea that I'm hooked on. It's always nice to get away and relax with cups of tea. There stuff is on the higher end of prices but quality is the best. Have yet to try there food out but I've seen many patrons eating and enjoying there food. I will try it out one day soon...To be continued
author: Jeff C.

description:
While wandering around the ferry building one day I happened to wander in here. I didn't intend on purchasing any teas, but after smelling many of them, I knew I couldn't walk out with at least a *little* something. 

I settled on their imperial chai and imperial jasmine pearls while my friend took a few ounces of the cloud mist. 

The tea is very good, especially the chai - no bitter aftertaste like you get with a brand like Tazo. I also like that is comes in heat sealed packets to preserve the freshness. 

What I didn't like was the service. The woman who helped us took moved at a glacial pace for no apparent reason. She also couldn't seem to remember what we wanted, and how many ounces. Another fellow was running around serving the restaurant customers, and he seemed on the ball, so I'm not sure what was up with the slacker behind the counter... it certainly shouldn't take 15min to package up 2oz of a couple kinds of tea.
author: Liz K.

description:
I really liked the ambience of this place. It reminded me a lot of my god-sisters dining room. I've never felt more at home in a restaurant before. 

We ordered some appetizers and all of them were good. I liked the Spicy Beef Noodles but they weren't spicy at all. 

I found it strange the tea had to be ordered individually. Each person chooses their own tea (very American and not Chinese at all) and everyone has a teacup that is refilled with water. I ordered my favorite kind of tea: Iron Goddess and it was okay but not really good and far from excellent. 

I would come back if other people wanted to eat here, but I didn't enjoy it so much that I would recommend it to my friends.
author: Kelly H.

description:
I keep coming back here for the tea noodles with pork.  Sure, it's served with angel hair pasta and would be vastly enhanced if they used fresh Chinese noodles.  Let me tell you that I like this dish so much I really don't care that it's served with angel hair pasta.  They use tea oil, and I'm pretty sure a spicy bean sauce, and it's just so satisfying especially on a cold day.  It always comes out piping hot, even when it's a to go order (cravings).  They're thoughtful about how they put it in the bag, tell you to keep it upright so's you don't spill any.  

The other food I've had here has been good, but not spectacular.  Nothing I would come here for instead of somewhere else.  For example, if you're going to eat dim sum go somewhere where they'll give you more bang for your buck, and more selection.  It's a small place.  

Tea has always been good here.  If someone in your party's never been, they'll do a truncated version of kung fu cha, where they'll rinse your tea leaves with hot water and have you smell the tea before and after the water's added.  I kinda wish they provided strainer's though, because it's just your cup with a lid to stop you from gulping down tea leaves.  You don't really have a choice but to overbrew, too.

Noodle note: You can get this dish with beef for an extra dollar, but the pork is the lighter and, in my opinion, tastier dish.
author: Amy N.

description:
1 star for a lovely tea experience.
1 star for the friendly staff 
1 star for the decor and overall ambience

(Minus 1 star for the terribly bland vegetarian selection of dim sum.)
author: E.Mo. ..

description:
Forget trying tea here.  Their tea is way overpriced and not worth it.  There is one thing and one thing only you should get here: the beef noodle soup.  It's one of the best beef noodle soups I've had in the Bay Area, even better than A&Js.  Their soup is not overpowered with spices and is full of the beef flavor.  You can specify spiciness ranging from mild to "super ultra spicy" (yes, my friend actually requested that once).  It definitely helps if you speak chinese.

They serve thin noodles with the soup.  I usually don't like thin noodles with soup because they get soggy.  However, the noodles here are made perfect and they soak up the flavor of the soup.

One drink you can consider getting is the Lychee Black Tea.  Goes great with the beef noodle soup.

YUM YUM YUM!

Don't try anything else though.  I've tried most of them and quite frankly, it was a disaster.
author: Tako B.

description:
Had lunch here so late it was almost dinner. The place was almost empty; everyone else seemed to be at the wine bar next door ;-) 

They have a nice selection of high quality teas, but not the huge number of teas on the tea tasting menu that Samovar has. The Imperial  doesn't seem to be as much of a scene as Samovar, probably due to its location in the Ferry Building and the fact that it closes at 6 pm. 

I had the orchid oolong, which I enjoyed very much in spite of not liking the gaiwan presentation. Gaiwan presentation means the tea is put into a rather small cup, then the water is added. You hold the saucer with the cup in it with your left hand, then with your right hand, employ the cup cover like a strainer to hold back the tea leaves while you sip the tea. Maybe the waitress put a lot of tea in my cup, but by the time the leaves unfurled and expanded, there wasn't room for much water in the cup. 

I ordered the dim sum sampler platter; it arrived much later than the tea - I was beginning to think it wasn't coming at all.  It was worth the wait. There was quite a lot of food for $6.50: 2 wontons, 2 shu mai filled with what tasted like cornmeal mush with tasty bits in it - very unusual, 2 rice paper dumplings with shrimp and mushroom filling, a perfectly cooked eggroll filled with tofu, cabbage, etc., a steamed bun with garlic chive and ??mushroom?? filling, and a steamed bun filled with red bean paste. The eggroll filling was a little bland, but everything else was very good.

$5 for the cup of tea and a gigantic (for 1 person) tea pot of hot water.
I enjoyed the orchid oolong so much that I bought some to take home, along with some Ceylon black tea.
author: Debi L.

description:
This place is beautiful. And I love tea. And I'm getting married and planning to have a Chinese tea ceremony. So I called on Imperial Tea Court to reserve their venue for the event. Was quoted pricing, discussed time and what I needed (for them to make some tea and otherwise leave the rest up to my family). Was told over the phone by a female representative that we were booked. I tried to give a credit card number to secure the reservation. None was needed, I was told. Just call a few weeks before the event to finalize the details. Fine. That was late last fall. 

Fast forward three or four months. We happened to be near the ferry building. Oh, I say to fiance, let's go in and give them our money and decide how we want the place laid out for us. We meet a white dude with a mullet sort of haircut and I tell him of our reservation and desire to finalize plans. He starts talking about tables and food. No, I explain, chinese wedding tea ceremony involves us kneeling and serving tea in one spot, no food and no tables necessary. Continue to explain that we just need to pay a deposit and decide on the layout. He starts quoting different prices and I tell him what I got from the corporate rep over the phone. $8 for each person for tea only, $12 per person for tea and food. He adds it up and decides he needs to call the owner to confirm everything. Fine. Calls the owner and she is not fine with it, apparently they do not have my reservation on file AND they will "lose too much money" on us by charging us $8 a head for some tea for 35 people on Saturday afternoon. EXCUSE ME?! Plus the room fee of a couple hundred dollars mind you! They are telling me that this would lose them money, a large amount of money that would be had by entertaining regular patrons at this time instead of honoring the reservation I had already made and was ensured that it stood firm. I don't even need the staff to do anything except make tea, I even have my own tea set so I don't need them to use anything, serve anything, wash anything, and still they will not honor their word. Next come the audacious suggestion that I do it at a different time! It's my freaking WEDDING DAY, I don't have ANOTHER TIME available for god's sake! I tell mullet man point blank that they are now ruining my wedding day. This is how people become bridezillas. Grace, the owner, and mullet man still offer me nothing and are content with standing me up. I actually cannot believe that a business would conduct themselves this way. I even remember the woman on the phone I initially spoke with saying they had done such events before; so why don't they have this routine down? 

REALLY UNPROFESSIONAL. Let it be known people, $8 for cup of tea is too little for these people. I am not sure what they expect for pouring some hot water on top of some lotus seeds, but apparently over $500 for an hour of their time (and remember they wouldn't actually have to do anything during this hour) is far too little.
author: Thlel Yan D.

description: Of all the tea places I've been in the city this place was the worst. The water in the tea pot wasn't even hot. The service was eh. The spicy noodles a) weren't spicy, b) lukewarm, and c) tasted like the packaged noodles you buy in the form cups. I wasn't impressed by much here. If you have a tea fetish like I do there a bunch of other places to try before this one.
author: Michael S.

description:
After a long morning of walking around at the Farmer's Market on Saturday, the Imperial Tea Court was a nice place to rest our tired stinky feet. Seriously, we took off our shoes and aired our feet while sipping tea on the this long couch like platform. 

It was interesting to watch our server brew our tea right in front of us. **Note: Monkey Picked Oolong Tea is false! Our server informed us that humans are doing the monkey's job of picking tea now. **

Overall, I had a nice experience but was disappointed that I wasn't drinking the actual monkey picked tea. But if you ever need a place to rest or air your feet, Imperial Tea Court is the place!
author: Alysha L.

description:
Everything Bambooo S. said.  The Imperial Tea Court is the gold standard by which I judge all other tea places, and one of the few places in the US where you can buy high-end and rare teas of international quality.  Some of the tea you can get here isn't available anywhere else, some of it will never be made again, and some of it will taste different with each season.  The teas (and fine collectible teaware) are hand selected by the proprietor, who is internationally known as a leading figure in western tea culture.  

This is a tea house, not a restaurant, adjust expectations accordingly.  Do not come here with gwai lo ignorance, scoff at the (reasonable) pricing and expect to be supersized.  Even when I'm hungry I have never found the portions to be too small, and as a vegetarian I think the selection is just fine.  The flavor is on the delicate side, but you don't want the food to overpower the tea.  And yes, you can get a huge cup of watered down, boiled-to-death tea from Peets for a dollar, but keep in mind that what they put in a tea bag is what they sweep off the floor of the tea processing plant.  

If you are open-minded and just learning or a more seasoned tea-o-phile this place is highly recommended.  Otherwise, save the good stuff for people who know how to appreciate it.
author: Pinky S.

description:
Are the people writing these reviews completely retarded? This is one of the premiere destinations for tea in the US. The hand-selected, hand-crafted tea is of such quality that people travel from China to buy it and take back home. Alice Waters is a regular. If you think think $5 a cup is too much to pay for tea that retails for $600 a pound then please stick with Peet's and don't waste the good stuff. If you think the service is slow just because the courteous, knowledgeable staff takes the time to discuss the tea with each client, maybe you would be happier at McDonalds.

The delicious, organic food tastes like authentic Chinese home-cooking...if only real Chinese moms could cook so well. The pork stew, beef noodles, dragonwell dumplings, and vegetarian spring rolls are particular standouts.  Imperial Tea Court is a destination for gourmands, not grazers. Come expecting an amazing gustatory experience, couched in a bewitching casual, low-key ambience. Considering the value delivered the prices are extraordinarily low.

No it's not the best venue for grabbing a quick bite or a "big gulp." If that's what you're looking for, eat some of the abundant mediocre food in the Ferry Bldg and stop griping about this place. I tried Out the Door and found it ersatz and appalling. I love the Ferry Bldg Imperial Tea Court. I think it's one of San Francisco's dining treasures.
author: Bambooo S.

description:
Just returned from an early "dinner" from here. Hadn't planned on it, but the wine bar next to it was full, so my friend and I decided to give this place a shot. 

If you like spicy food, you're in luck. They actually get what it means when someone requests for something to be prepared "super, super spicy." I had the spicy beef noodle soup. It was spicy alright. They can also make it mild if you are not into getting your tongue burned like I am. The broth is not overly salty, and the beef is tender and juicy. I'm not sure why I was surprised, maybe I wasn't expecting it to be any good. Remember when you order that the portion is Asian-sized (read: small). We also had the pork buns. You can save yourself the trouble though. It was dry, plain, and you can easily get much better pork buns in any decent dim sum place. 

Last note: Whatever you do, do try their tea. They have such a huge selection, and while I can't speak for the more traditional chinese tea they have on the menu, the iced green tea and hibiscus tea (slightly sweeten, only very slightly) we had was right on. Perfect for a warm summer day...
author: Selena L.

description:
I would never go to this place again, it used to be okay, I used to go since it was the only chinese place to go in the Embarcadero, but now I would go to Chinatown for tea and chinese food.

This place is way overpriced, something was wrong with the tea that I bought there, and it takes then way too long to prepare the meals, but what makes me not want to go there anymore is the attitude of the employees. They were rude. 

One star for the decoration only, otherwise this place is disappointing.
author: Tim F.

description:
Ah, a wonderful place to sit down and relax with a light snack and a cup of tea after walking down from Fisherman's Wharf. What was I doing at Fisherman's Wharf you say? My mom was in town, and she wanted to go. Mom really liked the decor of this place.

They are quite knowledgeable about tea here. They weren't overtly snooty about it either, but eager to help others learn. The teas we had were quite good. I keep meaning to go back now that this year's harvest should be in. I was near the Ferry Building Saturday, but that's not the time to go inside there, especially on a beautiful sunny day. 

Yeah, I don't think this is a place to eat. It's a place to relax with tea. Simple, and to the point.
author: neil c.

description: Try their spicy noodle soup. I ordered the Vegetarian non-spicy noodle soup and it was so good that I had to return again for more. It was infused with a delicious tea flavor, something you will not taste anywhere else. It has a unique taste and the noodles are great because it's thin enough to be appetizing. I really recommend this dish!
author: Tammy C.

description:
Had a delicious late tea here on Sunday afternoon. I ordered the Topaz Puerh - described as "An especially full-bodied gold-tip Puerh tea with superior richness, depth of color and a long, smooth finish." It was smoky and nutty but extremely pure! Very good - almost used an entire pot of very hot water with it. My companion ordered the Imperial Green Tea, served with less hot water, described as "Striking leaves with enchanting floral aroma and unexpected depth of flavor".

Can't wait to try more!
author: Mariangela S.

description:
Tea = 5 stars.
Service = 2 stars.
Wontons = 2 stars.
Soup = 1 star (too oily).
Chairs = hard. My butt hurt.
author: Mi M.

description: Poppy and girlfriend had such a fun tea tasting here!   Our cute server explained a bit about different teas, we sniffed six and picked two.  Very yummy and fun, so different from just grabbing a mug of tea at a coffeeshop.  Ended up buying an ounce of very fragrant jasmine pearl for about eight dollars.
author: Poppy C.

description: I went for the tea tasting and presentation on Sat with my groupon and was sadly disappointed.  This is the first groupon I felt like was not worth it, it was $15 for $30 worth of tea...what did we get?  umm two cups of tea!!!  It did not include food or anything else, way over priced.  The atmosphere was nice and I guess it would be fine if you paid like uhh 8 bucks for it, because the tea was normal, not fantastically worth $30.  I should have bought the Samovar groupon instead doh!
author: Angie Y.

description: Food was average. Portions were small and dry. They charge extra for private tea making and pouring demo at your table.  Don't do it. It's a rip-off. Atmosphere was decent.
author: Isabella L.

description:
I came here with a coworker for lunch one day to catch up and girl gossip.  

I ordered the vegetarian curry with rice, and tea.  It was pretty tasty and nice.  The atmosphere was nice and the service was fairly good too.  Although I don't have anything negative or positive to say, for some reason, I didn't leave the restaurant thinking that i HAD to come back.
author: Brenda H.

description:
Where to start?

I stopped in with my father for lunch.  I have a general rule about avoiding the overpriced businesses at the Ferry Plaza.  The food is typically overpriced and oversanitized to appease the delicate palates of the bridge and tunnel crowd.  This place did nothing to prove me wrong.

I knew what I wanted, so I ordered (spicy noodles and some white tea).  My father was brave enough to try and solicit suggestions from the staff.  Ugh.

The tea was fine, the presentation was not.  Certainly not $5 worth of fine by any stretch of the imagination.  If I wanted high quality tea, I'd mail order it from Upton.  Hell, you can call them and they're happy to help you pick out teas you might like.  Here?  The waitress was extremely reluctant to recommend any sort of tea pairing to my father.  She was down right condescending to him.

I'll agree 100% with the other posters who pointed out that you do not leave some tea to steep while you drink it.  Lots of English black teas can take it.  The more delicate green and white teas cannot.  Your tea will taste like stewed tea leaves.  That this place expects you to not remove your tea leave at all shows how little they know about tea.  That they explain different brewing temperatures for different teas is great.  But they only give you one pot of water.  So. Again.  Don't order green teas here lest you end up with a cup of stewed green tea.  For as much as they charge they ought to get these things right.
