So, after that, I decided to dig into the noodles.  I opted for vegetarian (which is often a mistake in some restaurants, but I felt like something light) vs beef or pork.  These were not light.  Once I made my way through the huge mount of lettuce, I discovered that the noodles were, as other commenters pointed out, essentially what you'd buy at the store.  Maybe a step above the dry noodles in foam cups, but certainly no better than the perishable noodles.  For $12 I expected a helluva lot more from the noodles.

But hey, maybe the magic was in their hyped broth, right?  Nope.  As I splashed a few drops of broth while trying to dig through the mess of lettuce, the first thing I noticed was that it was that the broth was quite oily.  Okay.  Maybe that's because it's spicy, right?  Lots of places use chili oil to spice things up.  Wrong again.  It was not spicy.  Well, at least they balanced the delicate flavors in the broth with skill aplomb, right?  Nope.  The broth was a salty oily mess.  Yuck.

So what does one do with a salty oily mess in between sips of hot tea?  If you answered drink some ice cold water, you'd have read my mind.  Apparently they don't give water out by default.  That's fine.  We're in San Francisco.  We like to conserve water.  So I tried to pique the waitress' attention.  Every time I tried this, she'd smile at me and run away quickly.  At some point she finally acted like she was going to come over.  Then one of the 'regulars' came in and she became more interested in helping him.  For the life of me I could not get either of the waitresses to come over to the table.  Even when we were ready to leave (chopsticks laying across the bowl, full cup of tea pushed away from me, father's empty plate... nope.. that's not a sign we're done) they were insistent upon ignoring us.  I had to walk over and demand the cheque... and then demand that they give me change.

Why someone would bother coming here regularly is beyond me.  Perhaps I looked too much like an uncivilized troll to be worth providing service to.  Whatever.

Food preference is inherently subjective.  However, in this case, I'd say if you actually like their food or tea... you've probably not tried a decent restaurant.  FFS people, the selection of teas on the menu, it's not that impressive.  If you want to be blown away check out Adagio or Upton and do it yourself at home.

If you want a quaint tea house for the ambiance, well, they fail here too.  Whomever posted about the oddly sized chairs and tables was spot on.
author: Alex Z.

description:
Soul-less overpriced commodified tea house experience. This is not high quality artesnal tea. Plus the decor is like Starbucks. Its a slick aesthetic with an obvious branding style for their chain of Starbucks-like tea houses.

Really, why would you go here when you have quality and interesting tea houses in SF like Samovar and Leland Tea and about a dozen spots in China town that serve authentic artesenal small-farm Chinese tea (i.e. the good stuff).

And their prices are literally like twice (literally Silver white tea for $160/pound??? Are you kidding me? Its half that at Silk Roads and they're importing directly from China) the price of Rainbow or Silk Road Teas, which offer really excellent selections.
author: Audrey L.

description:
Overpriced and underwhelming.

I got the Bejing Style Stew, and it was white rice, with boiled cabbage and beef. The beef was decent, but being Asian, and paying 12.50 for something that probably cost a total of two dollars to make really detracted from the whole experience.

This part of the review doesn't affect the rating, but I ordered some oolong tea with it (at about $3.50! Expensive!), but I spilled it before I got a chance to try it. So that sucked.
author: Jenton L.

description: This tea shop was pretty empty when we visited noonish while neighboring shops were bustling. It's not hard to see why. Perhaps in an effort to appear authentically Asian they forgot about customer service and comfort. The tables had a low bar so my boyfriend couldn't fit his legs underneath. We ordered two cups of tea and an order of the tea dumplings. They were both quite good but the atmosphere just wasn't there.
author: Janie W.

description: Shared the $20 meal with the husband today.  We got a pot of tea, spring rolls, and a bowl of spicy noodles with pork.  The tea was flavorful and came piping hot in a tea cup with lid.  Very cute.  The spring rolls were really oily and the sauce needed a little extra something.  The noodle soup was actually pretty good.  The noodles have the perfect texture and the broth has a lot of flavor with a kick of spice to make it just right.  This place has a HUGE selection of teas and tea sets that could delight a person really into their tea.  This place was OK but a little pricey.
author: Nina L.

description:
Eh. This place is only okay. 
I'm no tea connoisseur, although the lychee black tea and the barley tea I've had there isn't bad. But honestly, it's not any different, for instance, than the barley green tea that is served gratis at Japanese restaurants in J-town. 

The only thing (or two to be accurate that this place has got going for it is 1) the spicy noodle soup [beef or vegetarian; not the pork one] and 2) the tea broth wontons. The other stuff (dim sum fare) is waaay pricey for stuff you can pick up in the freezer section of 99 Ranch. Also, the service is s--l--o--w. Definitely budget 1.5 hours+ for lunch there, which I'm sure is a luxury for most folks.
author: lily l.

description:
2 chineeze waitresses are some b'i't'c'h'es.
Overall it's a cool spot to contemplate over some bad ass tea.

Grace - keep it up! :)
author: Cat of a Donut J.

description:
My husband and I have been wanting to check this place out for the longest time, The decor and the feel of the place is really cool, and we thought  it would be a fun experience. When we finally went in December, we were extremely disappointed.

The items on the menu sounded really, really good and I'm a dim-sumaholic. Though it seemed a bit pricey, we thought,"Why not?."


They list a lot of teas on their menu, but the thing is, they were out of the 2 teas we had chosen.  Being of Chinese descent, my family would always order Bo Nay tea with our dim sum, ( it helps with digestion) so I thought we would just stick with that. When I asked if they had it, the waitress didn't know what the heck I was talking about and said that she was not Chinese. I asked if there was someone else she could ask and she just walked away without saying a word. She didn't say that she would go find out or anything, we didn't know if that meant she was going to ask another employee or if she was going to take a break or what.

She came back 5 minutes later and said she didn't think they had that. Feeling a little frustrated, I asked her what they did have that she could recommend.  She looked at me like I was speaking Martianese. It would have been great if t she would have suggested something else  and been a little helpful so we could just have some damn tea.

My husband and I looked at the menu again and chose a tea and ordered some dim sum. The dim sum portions were sooo small and expensive, it was ridiculous.  Oh, don't expect the pork bun to be a 
barbeque pork bun like you'll find at other tea houses and dim sum restaurants. It is a PORK bun. A dry, soggy-ass chunk of pork. I've eaten pork buns all my life and have never had anything so awful.

I've noticed that people keep mentioning that it is a TEA House not a restaurant, well then they shouldn't  serve any food. How about tea and crackers instead? I could roll with that!

The waitress was very unfriendly, and the service was lousy.  bring any It was not a good experience.
author: Dee T.

description:
Hubby's Review:

I'm not a big tea drinker but I love the servers here.
author: Mr. and Mrs. L.

description: I am not a tea connoisseur, so this place was fine to get a taste of what the experience may be like.  We enjoyed the two loose green teas we tried.  The dim sum sampler platter was disappointing, though.  Looked better than it tasted. Definitely touristy.
author: Gwen G.

description: Hmm..I'm not a fan but I'll file this in my "perfect for the tea connoisseur" category when shopping for gifts...the quality of the tea was only ok, not very fragrant or soothing. Perhaps it was due to the leaves getting stuck in my teeth. They served it in a cup with a lid which I hated. Mr X had some edibles and declared the soup noodles delicious. Snacks looked so-so...stale dim sum didn't quite appeal to my palate when I knew there was an abundance of baguettes and butter to be found in close proximity. So for gifting, a decent variety of loose tea leaves sold by weight as well as lots of fancy tea pots and other tea related merchandise. On the pricier side, but definitely unique.
author: helen l.

description: Silly me thought we could prance into the ferry building on a random Saturday and grab lunch at Slanted Door; boy was I wrong.  We were denied a table and didn't want to do the 'float around the bar' dance to fight for a seat. Defeated, my gf and I glumly roamed around and stumbled across the tea court.  It looked promising with a few patrons slurping up noodles and enjoying the tea so we gave it a shot.  Big mistake!  The food here is subpar - their most popular dish, a spicy noodle offering was no good.  The "imported noodles" tasted like safeway select thin spaghetti noodles and the egg rolls were of the frozen variety a la Costco (my suspicions at least).  The dish my gf had was interesting - it was wontons served in some jasmine tea broth, wontons weren't bad and the broth was unique.  Prob won't be back for the food, can't speak to the tea as we didn't have any...
author: Ricky S.

description:
I didn't even know they served food here.

I've come for the tea several times, and I've always been very impressed. The staff is very knowledgeable and helpful, and they're not like those elitist snobs who look down on you for not knowing the how to pour 17th century style Chinese tea. They'll even demonstrate.

I always get the "earthiest" tea they have (it smells like mud), and it puts you in a pretty nice place. Much more effective for relaxing, cleansing the system, or getting rid of malaise. On flavor and strength, this is the best tea I've had in the city so far.
author: Jared S.

description: I love the Ferry Building for all that it is and all that it has, but I can't say the same about the Imperial Tea Court.  Maybe I should have came just for tea, which they do a great job of presenting and teaching you how to drink properly.  The problem is that I was hungry and we never tried their food, so we decided to give them a try.  Lacking a full kitchen, the food isn't properly prepared from the soggy dim sums and the bland and soggy spicy noodles.  I did have a problem with one dim sum and a foreign object, as well as the nasty iced green tea.  In hindsight, I would recommend coming here for tea service only and to get your food fill elsewhere.
author: Jason A.

description:
This place is a complete rip-off in every sense. I came here for lunch with a friend and we waited 20 minutes for service even though the place was less than half full. Eventually, my friend had to flag down our very impatient, scowling waiter so we could order. I ordered the beef stew which was painfully subpar. It was a bowl of mostly rice, with a sprinkling of broccoli, and bland meat. Any place in Chinatown could've served the same thing  for $4 in 5 minutes, instead of $14.50 in another 20 minutes. 

My tea leaves came in the tea cup with the teapot full of scalding water. The waiter wordlessly poured the water into my cup, put a lid on the cup, then left. No explanation as to how long I should let it steep or, most importantly, how to drink it. I've had English tea in plenty of places, and I've had tea in countless Chinatown dim sum places, but I've never seen it served like this. I noticed there was a strainer inside the teapot full of hot water so I dumped the tea in my cup into the teapot. Later when I asked our waiter about it, he told me the tea was supposed to be drunk with the cup loaded with leaves. The lid was supposed to be used as a strainer even though it was, in every possible way, just a lid. Anyway, after he saw the mistake I made FROM HIS LACK OF EXPLANATION, he stated,"You'll just have to drink it like that now." Does it make logical sense to drink a scalding cup of tea leaves with the lid on? Perhaps they drink like this in China, but this pretentious time and money vacuum is in the Ferry Berry amidst many people who might not be familiar with the tea customs of China. Was a simple 1 or 2 sentence explanation too much to do?

This place robbed us of our precious money, time, and good mood. Also, the height of their chairs and tables makes it impossible to cross one's legs. If you have fat thighs, you should pick a table that has you sitting Indian style. Or better yet, you can just spare yourself the misery and go somewhere else.
author: Faye S.

description: Went here a few days ago because we were perusing the ferry building and got hungry. It looked nice inside and we were only hungry for a snack, so it seemed to be a good choice.  Unfortunately this was not the case. We went to the counter to ask for a table and were greeted by a very unwelcoming waitress.  She barely spoke two words to us as she showed us to our table, and didn't get any more chatty as the meal went by.  We ordered a vegetarian bun and vegetarian egg rolls; while the buns  came in a timely manner, the egg rolls took FOREVER. When they came they were so molten that we burned our tongues scarfing them down because of our hunger.  In that respect it is impossible to know whether they actually tasted good or our tongues rendered them delicious because the taste buds were burnt beyond repair. Anyhow, beyond the egg rolls, the vegetarian buns were a complete disappointment.  They were filled with nasty, bitter cow cud-like greens, and opening them emitted a smell of death.  We ended up dumping the greens out and eating just the bun-- to the disapproval of rude waitress.  The only shining light in the end of this bleak tunnel was the tea, which appeared to be very high quality and delicious.  In addition to the made to order ones inside the restaurant, they also had bags for sale that looked good. Unfortunately it was too hot outside to order any, so we can't specifically comment on that, however we will not be returning here to find out if they were in fact good or not.
author: Shep And Chats P.

description: This is my favorite place in SF for tea.  I go straight for the Imperial Green tea which is the best quality tea (and the most expensive) you can get there.  They serve it the correct way in the porcelain cups and at the right temperature and you can re-steep it a bunch of times.  I usually like having tea here right after I chug some oysters down at Hog Island.  The Imperial green gives you a nice buzz and makes you feel good, unlike most coffee's do to me.  Thay have some great tea's to go and the people that work there seem to know what they are doing, rather then Teavana which is more commercial.
author: Mitch A.

description: i love the yin hao jasmine silk pyramid tea bags! thanks to my friend's sister for getting me a variety of tea from this place. the tea smells and tastes divine!!!
author: Helen Y.

description: Oh, man, the dimsum I had here was some of the best. They infuse the insides with tea and it's amazing. Also, I liked that our server was very nice in explaining the proper methods for drinking tea, which was also amazing itself. And with so many cool places to stop in the Ferry Building, this makes for a great place to eat and drink.
author: Patrick G.

description:
I enjoy Chinese tea but was disappointed during my visit to Imperial Tea Court.

For a restaurant that purports to serve rare and high-end Chinese tea, very little attention was paid to the proper preparation of the tea.  For example:

- For the best flavor, the brewing vessel should be preheated by rinsing it with hot water.  This was not done.

- The tea was brewed in a gaiwan (a cup with a lid), but no cup was supplied to pour the finished tea into after it had brewed.  Normally, tea is brewed in a gaiwan but then poured into a separate cup to drink.  This prevents the tea from brewing too long.  Although it's not unheard of to drink tea off the top of the leaves - "grandpa style" - it's what you would do at home with average quality tea, not what you expect when you go to a tea house.

- The water wasn't hot enough.  With a pu-erh tea that needs nearly boiling water to get the best flavor, I was served warm water (say, 170 degrees).  The water might have been suited to a delicate green tea but not to a robust pu-erh tea.

I strongly recommend that you avoid the Imperial Tea Court.
author: David W.

description: Not terrible, but there's a reason this is one of the least crowded restaurants and shops in the Ferry Building.  The dim sum is really sub-par.  The tea we had was good.
author: Anonymous P.

description: I can't speak to the tea since I didn't have any, but the food was just....ugh. It was clean tasting and all, and it was edible, but the flavor combinations were just wrong. Service was almost non-existent, and it's not like they were crowded in the least to justify it.
author: Jiga M.

description: Nice, but not that nice. $30 for tea and a nosh is kinda redic.
author: Stephen G.

description: Yes, this is in the middle of the Ferry Building so you do get the tourist crowd, but in all honesty, this was the first place I went when I visited San Francisco five years ago... and now I live here and I still go to the Imperial Tea Court! I think it's my oasis to the bustle of the Ferry Building and the downtown itself. The dim sum is delicious and the teas are always fresh. It's a great alternative to the rest of the Embarcadero area without spending a fortune.
author: Deirdre P.

description: Great place for your Chinese herbal tea fix. With an abundant selection, from your Olongs to your white teas, It would be very hard not to find what you are looking for at this place. The food menu consists of savory snacks to go along with your tea but, they also serve Tea braised Neiman Ranch Beef, Rice, Noodles, Dim Sum, and Vegetables bowls. The staff is very nice and accommodating as well.
author: Marco M.

description:
We visited the Imperial Tea House for their Dim Sum Afternoon Tea special on 8/10. It was quiet and cozy - only 2 other tables seated. There are so many different teas to choose from - maybe 30 or more. The menu divides them into black, green, red, white, etc. I chose the black breakfast tea (yes, I love my english style teas) and my hubby went with a white floral tea (can't remember specifics). Our server was...  interesting. Kind of had a hippie, zen vibe going on... tall, lanky, maybe half asian, with a long beard. Anyhow... once our tea was served,  he explained how to drink it with the cup and lid on it. This was also interesting, as my first sip of tea came with a bunch of tea leaves. After a few more sips, I finally got the hang of it. 
Our dim sum came a few minutes later: a few kinds of dumplings, eggroll and dipping sauce. My favorite were the shrimp dumplings and the tiny pork ones. 
It was a nice experience... but we left there hungry... only to stop by Ciao Bella to get some sugar into our system! 
If you're hanging around the Ferry Building during the late afternoon, stop by to get a cup of tea...  I'd skip the dim sum though. There are better options in the building, even if it's a crusty roll with butter.
author: Candyce P.

description: The dim sum was way better than I anticipated. It was cool that you could get almost everything on the sampler platter vegetarian. It was actually very relaxing within the busy Ferry Building. I thought it was pricey though. And "gaiwan" seemed much less exotic after I learned it means covered bowl.
author: Amy E.

description: I speak only of the tea man and purchasing tea for home brewing.  Each time I visit, I feel slightly uneasy because of my limited tea knowledge and the overwhelming selection. Nevertheless, despite my inexperience, the tea man has always come to my rescue, encouraging me to sniff any and all, providing me with great suggestions, and calming my tea jitters. Such excellent service and always so polite. I leave feeling happy with my purchases and eager to taste new flavors.
author: Faye P.

description:
I'm giving this 3 instead of 2 stars because the tea really was good and the people were pretty friendly (if a little slow to acknowledge that we were standing around, completely unsure of what the procedure was for getting a table). It was too expensive and, while I'm sure the gaiwan tea-serving style is authentic somewhere, it was counterintuitive and weird to us. At first we tried scopping the leaves out after each infusion, but eventually I gave up and just did as the others did: push the leaves back with the lid and drink through the crack. But really, what if you don't drink the tea fast enough and the liquid at the bottom gets overbrewed and bitter and gross, (as green tea is wont to do)? I don't really understand, but some things are not for me to know, I suppose. My fancy green tea (the suggestion when I indicated I liked my tea "grassy") was beautiful and quite tasty, but I wouldn't buy it because I am too cheap. My boyfriend was not overly impressed with the white tea he had, preferring the jasmine pearl white tea he bought at Tea Time in Palo Alto.

I don't know what was up with the spicy vegetarian noodles with secret spices. Is there MSG in there or something? My boyfriend said the broth tasted moldy to him if he ate some after sipping his tea. The mushroom steamed buns were all right and so were the red bean paste buns; both made much better tea food than the noodles, but the boyfriend didn't feel up to braving one of the other food vendors. Oh well. Some other time.
author: Emily C.

description: Ambiance, a quiet nook in the noisy Ferry Building.  The dim sum sampler plate, beyond average, nearly tasteless and not worth the $$.  I loved the quiet of the place, but really, I was amazed at how tasteless it was.
author: Donna H.

description: Annoyed with this place since I called to make a reservation (I had a Groupon which was about to expire) and they said they had nothing available before 4pm.  I made plans to go elsewhere in the Ferry Building for lunch, but walked by the Imperial Tea Court, and there were only about 2 people seated!  Not sure why they said they were full.  I suppose they don't like Groupon customers.  Well, I wasted $15 (will be more careful about buying groupons or use them earlier)  and will never try this place since they didn't seem to want my business.
author: Maria D.

description: What an experience! I normally prefer happy hour, but some cold nights demand hot tea (offered in dozens upon dozens of delicious varieties).  The staff is incredibly accommodating; explaining elements of traditional tea service, educating about the varieties available and plainly making drinking tea here a relaxing experience. I recently had a sort of peach and ginger concoction... Incredible!
author: Jenni D.

description: Went here with a group of girls for lunch.  The food is very tasty.  I had the spicy noodle soup with pork.  It was a little spicy and savory.  This is a nice meal on a cold day.  I also had the everyday white tea.  The portions are small so if you're hungry I would recommend ordering an appetizer with an entree.  I am not an expert on drinking loose leaf tea where the lid of the cup is used to prevent the leaves from being consumed.  This was an experience.  The tea selection is excellent.
author: Ginny M.

description: When Groupon offered a tea tasting for two to this place, I decided to spring for it.  My nine-year-old son is crazy about tea and loves to smell the fragrances and sample the flavors--pretty fabulous when you think about a kid liking that kind of thing.  So we went.  What a sweet atmosphere, too.  Rows of jars of teas.  Lovely lanterns hanging from above.  It was quite charming.  Our server was fabulous.  She took a good deal of time explaining about the saucer, the cup, the lid that serves as a strainer so as not to get tea leaves in the drinking cup.  She explained about the qualities of each of the six teas from which we could select for our tasting.  And then she really stayed with us during the tasting session, returning frequently to ensure we had enough hot water and to refill our tiny cups.  We ordered two dim sum dishes and cookies.  There's no way to say this nicely.  The food left little to be desired.  I'm a big dim sum fan, and I've had far better elsewhere.  My son gobbled the cookies down because, well, he's nine and pretty much always hungry for a snack.  Marginal food aside, our experience here was delightful.  Do people say delightful any more? Well, I did.  And I'm glad  I did.  For the experience and the service, you have to give the Imperial Tea Court credit.  They gave me and my son a lovely memory and a moment in time.
author: Shadi G.

description: This is a place I have been curious about for awhile and despite the other location within walking distance from my home, I have not tried it yet. Today was the day. The interior looks very relaxing and soothing. The plethora of tea varieties is overwhelming...so many from which to choose. I had eaten lunch, so I was only in the market for an iced beverage. I ordered the iced lychee tea to go and it was delicious. Not too perfume-y, not too sweet, very refreshing. I think high quality tea loses something when it's encased in a plastic to-go container, but that was the reality. It took quite a long time to get this beverage, but the taste was superb. I will definitely return to purchase tea and try something else, tho' I would not be going if a time crunch were looming. I am going to investigate the Berkeley location next.
author: Suzanne F.

description: This is some high class chinese resturant! I think it was made for the tourist. It is pretty clean there, the food is expensive but it taste like your typical chinese food.  You would spend WAY less in Chinatown.
author: Janet Z.

description: This is the spot for great teas. It has wide variety of selection- black, oolong, green, white teas you name it.   Service is great and accomodating, I always ask to smell the teas before purchasing it. Some of my favorites including chai black tea, peach tea, everyday jasmine, white peony and china white chrysanthemum.  They also small but tasty selection of  dimsum.  This is great place to take out of town guests or to just have tea with friends after browsing through the farmer's market.
author: Belle M.

description:
love the food. the tea was pretty good, but it didn't blow my mind. not bad respite from the rich hippy feel of the Ferry building.

there must be more authentic Chinese tea rooms in SF. I've got my radar out...
author: G Z.

description: I have been here several times and I thought the teas were great.  I have tried a number of them and even been there to eat once.  I thought the service was excellent as were the cute shirts that the staff had to wear.  I thought that was a good touch.
author: A K.

description: I went there with a groupon for tea tasting.  We were about to be seated but when the lady saw the groupon she said you have to come back with a reservation.  They were pretty empty but they said you need a reservation and we can take you in 4 hours.  I said we would come back the next day. I called to make a reservation.  They didn't seem happy about a groupon.  Maybe they loose money on this.  I don't know the background I just know they didn't like the fact I had a coupon.   I made a reservation for the next day and we were twenty minutes late (we have a young baby).  When we got there there were only 2 people at one table in the whole place.  The lady said you are late you missed your reservation.  You can come back in 4 hours.   There were a couple of people working and only 2 customers!  I said I'm sorry we have a young baby and that was the second time we went there and we can't hang around for four hours or come back again.  She said she called but she did not.  There was no message or missed call.  She probably called the wrong number if she did call at all.  I said this was the second time we tried this.  It's not working out.  Can we please have a refund.  She said they can't give it and to call groupon because they took the money.  It was a big waste of our time and they just did not seem interested in costumers with the groupon.   They did not care to accommodate us and she was relieved I just left.  We didn't have that experience anywhere else.  I would say don't get coupons for this place and don't bother to go - with our without a coupon.  Enjoy a better experience at another place.
author: May S.

description: I am revising my review from 2 stars to 4 stars.  I have been here 3 times now.  The first experience was pretty bad, but now that I have been back twice, I really like it.  Their iced teas are especially delicious.  I have tried about 4 items on the menu, and I like them all.  I love the wontons in jasmine tea broth.  I smell the jasmine as soon as the bowl arrives, but it doesn't taste too much like jasmine.  It's a very delicate flavor.  The service has been very friendly and pretty prompt.  It's a tea place, so if you are on your lunch hour and you are in need of lighting-fast service, this would not be the right place for you.  I think the quality of the food is very fresh too.
author: Kandi K.

description: We came here one time just to try this place out and thought the interior decor was pretty interesting...and that was about it...the food was so so and the tea wasn't too bad...I probably won't go back there any time though...
author: JenJen W.

description: What an understated little gem!  I'm not a hard core tea person but I've been very impressed with the food here.  I had lunch there last week and today (prior to my humongo letdown at Miette - see other review) and had the red hibiscus iced tea both times.  Beautiful and yummy!  The spicy pork noodles are indeed spicy and delish and the tea-infused wanton soup was equally delish.  It's never crowded and you'll pay about the same as you would at Taylor's or any of the other Ferry Building spots but without the noise and with nicely prepared food (although I'm certainly not one to turn my nose up at sweet potato fries at Taylors).
author: Nicole B.

description:
First of all, let me say that I really, really hope my experience today was some temporary glitch. The last time I went to this place, nearly two years ago, it was quite a pleasant experience. Today, not so much. 

They were clearly understaffed and it took quite a long time to get our waiter's attention to order. When one of my friends requested the vegetarian version of the dim sum plate, she was asked "Is shrimp OK?" 

We then waited quite a long time for our food. It didn't arrive, in fact, until we flagged down the other staffperson there and got him to check. 

As for the food itself, it was just OK, not great, and nowhere near worth the $9/plate. The issue was not so much the flavor but the fact that the wrappers and even some of the fillings were somewhat dried out, indicating that the dim sum had been sitting out for a while. 

Worst of all, we figured out halfway through the meal that they had swapped orders, giving my friend the full-meat version instead of the vegetarian version she had requested. (Luckily, she's not hard-core about this, but for someone else, it would have been disastrous.)

The servers themselves seemed overworked and not particularly happy to be where they were... something of a downer as well.

Yes, the tea itself was lovely, but really not worth the hassle.

I really hope that their management gets their act together and saves Imperial Tea Court; I know it's capable of serving up a better experience than this.
author: Katherine F.

description: OK dim sum but why don't they make good pork bao? Overdone chinese decor. Funny low tables that anyone near 6'0 can't sit at. Whenever someone tries, the chairs go CLACK CLACK CLACK on the concrete floor. Not good for a soothing zen atmosphere but then you are in a mall. My black tea was good, mom's green tea was... an acquired taste. Very limited food menu so you better be into the tea. Curry stew is good though. Call it 2.5 stars.
author: Dave K.

description: this place just makes me feel so relaxed.  amazing tea, and the staff is so helpful!  they never treat you like you're an idiot, no matter what kind of dumb questions you ask.  lots of vegetarian options on the food menu.  the dim sum is yummy and veggie spring rolls are amazing--i'm trying the noodles next and i'll let you know.  this is such a great quiet escape from the annoying bustle of a saturday afternoon farmer's market crowd.  i want all the tea ware.  the flowering teas are exquisite, but i am an oolong woman and have never been disappointed, no matter how many varieties i try.  they also have a great blog and twitter specials.  i've learned so much about tea from all the imperial tea mediums.  thank you guys!
author: kate s.

description: I came here to buy Pu-erh tea.  I bought three different kinds.  They were okay, but VERY over priced.  there's a tea store off clement street that has better tea for better prices.  This might be a good place to visit for tea in the shop, but I recommend that you buy your tea (to drink at home) elsewhere.
author: MyTwoCent s.

description: This place set up a nice tea service in terms of having a variety of all the tea types (white/green/oolongs/ pu-er) if a little shallow in its depth of exploring the more unknown varieties of each. The tea was delicious. The snacks which accompanied were pretty mediocore.. The gal pushed heavily the green tea covered walnuts, which we got as part of the snack sampler, but i found them pretty sugary and processed and liked the almonds best, as i think my date would concur. I love the simple act of great coversation over strong lovely tea, so i can't go any lower than 3 stars as they provided this and the Ferry Building is one of my favorite SF instiutions, foodie that I am, but overall I think SF offers much better spots for tea service, from China town to the wonderful Samovar.. and the food here offered as snacks clearly came out of bags flown over from Beijing, which is kinda gross.. Plus, no soy milk was available to "creamy" up my tea.. I know, i should be more hard core, but sometimes i like my tea like a soft cloud.. Anyway, a great time due to the company and nice tea, but not necessarily added to the rotation.
author: Rachel S.

description: I come here only for their spicy beef brisket noodle soup  (Ngau Yuk Meen).  I think it's better than A&Js (Cupertino / San Jose) because they don't overwhlem the soup with chilli oil or other flavors, but keep the beef soup flavor in tact.  You can ask for the chilli oil on the side if you want it spicier.  Cheap too for a filling bowl of noodles (the brisket is nice and soft).
author: Toto T.

description: The spicy beef teahouse noodles are so incredible.  I fantasize about them often.  Great tea selection and presentation.  One star down because they raised prices recently, and it wasn't super reasonable to begin with.  But great location and atmosphere.  Dim sum platter is just "meh" but I still get it every time because I like all the little treats.
author: audrey y.

description: This place isn't about the food.  If that's what you're looking for, there are plenty of better options in the ferry building.  But if you're looking for a huge selection of rare Chinese tea, you've found the best place in the city.
author: John D.

description:
the tea tasted ok (iced lichee green) but unforgivably- i sucked up a small piece of plastic through the straw, presumably from the pack of frozen litchees.  i don't have a problem of frozen lichees, but i do w/ swallowing plastic.  i spit it out.
the food was awful, the curry was tasteless (it really was- just bland), the dim sum all tasted the same- like steamed soggy warm dough packs.  the service was horrible - the hostess was annoyed and the waitress ignored my request for hot sauce.
given these prices, the whole experience should be better, this is the type of place that gives chinese food a bad name.
author: Kim Y.

description: We were attracted by the traditional Chinese look of this place. The tea is good, the beef stew is very nice, but the waiting time is definitely too long which took me 1 extra hour for my lunch break. If you are not in a hurry and into teas, then you can sit there enjoying teas. Not recommended for people who has a tight schedule. It always fun to explore a new place with the right person though.
author: David L.

description: I go here from time to time because I love the spicy noodles with beef, and it's close to my office.  The food is good, although at 11 bucks it's overpriced.  I suppose the main reason for my 2-star rating is the service.  Getting them to refill your drink is difficult--they don't check on you.  Also it's best to have cash that you can leave on the table when you're ready to go.  Even during lunchtime when you'd expect them to be used to turning over the tables quickly, you have to BEG for your check or get up and walk to the cashier to ask for it.  Tasty noodles though.
author: Jim D.
